LONDON, Printed for Sam. Smith at the' Princes Arms in St. Paul's Church-Yard. 1685.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p: THE rie of the following Tract, intimated near the beginning of it, was not uch a fictitious thing as the Reader may imagine. But tho' I really receiv'd a Viit from a Phyician, known to me, but by his Reputation purpoely to propoe to me his Objections againt the Corpucular Phyloophy, and he had a long conference with me about them; yet, becaue the Hitorical paages of that interview, cannot be circumtantially related in few words, I uppoe the Reader will willingly allow me, to imploy this Preface in giving him Advertiements about the cope and deign of the Treatie it uhers in.

I hall therefore advertie him, that he will be much mitaken, if he hall expect, as I perceive everal have done already, to find in this Book a Collection of Receits of Specifick
Remedies. For a moderate attention to the Title Page will enable him manifetly to dicern, that the following Paper in its own nature, and in the direct and immediate deign of it, is a Speculative dicoure; ince it tends but to how, that, in cae there be Specifick Medicines (as 'tis probable there are ome) their experienced vertues are reconcilcable to the principles of the Corpucular, or (as many call it) the new Philoophy; and at leat do not ubvert them; if thee Effects and Operations be not clearly explicable by them. And as this is the, avowed cope of the following Eay, o I choe to treat of it les like a Phyician than a Naturalit. For Phyicks being a Science, whoe large extent invites and warrants its Cultivaters, to earch into the nature and Phaenomina of things corporeal indefinitely; it mut often happen, that the Medicinal Art and this Science will be converant about the ame ubject, tho' in differing ways, and with differing copes.
For there are divers hurtful or advantageous accidents and changes of the humane Body, whereof the Naturalit takes notice, but as they are Phaenomina or changes produc'd by Natural caues in the Body of an Animal, whilt the Phyician coniders them as Symptoms of Dieaes, or Effects of Medicines, the former directing his Speculations to the dicovery of truth, and the other his Theory to the recovery of health. But becaue I ele where particularly conider the Cognation and ditinction, between the Dicipline that the Naturalit, and that which the Phyician cultivates, I hall for bear to mention them in this place; but rather acknowledge, that I carce doubt but that I might have inrich'd the following dicoure with ome choice particulars, if I would have perus'd and borrow'd from the learned writings of the famous Dr. Willis: But beides that I had not his Books at hand, I was unwilling to be prepoes'd or byas'd by his notions, and I preum'd
the Peron I wrote to would not be unwilling to ee, what, without their help, the conideration of the thing I treated of uggeted to me. About this I hall now proceed to oberve, that tho' the direct cope of the following dicoure, being to explicate the Phaenomena of ome bodies, which from their ue, are call'd Medicinal, and declare how poibly they may produce the Effects acrib'd to them, the enuing dicoure is for the main of a Speculative nature; yet the conequences that may be drawn from it, and the applications that in this indutrious Age are like to be made of ome things that it contains, may probably render it practical. For I have more than once oberv'd, that divers coniderable Remedies, and ome not unpromising methods too, have either remain'd unthought of, both by many Galenical Phyicians, and divers of their modern Antagonits too, or if propos'd by others, have been rejected or lighted, barely upon this uppoition,
that no rational account can be given of their way of working, or how they hould do good, and 'tis aid to be unworthy of a rational Phyician; to make ue of a Remedy, of whoe manner of operating he cannot give a reaon. How prejudicial it may be to many Patients, that Phyicians be prepoes'd with a bad opinion of an ueful Remedy, may be gues'd by him that hall conider, what multitudes of Teeming Women, that probably might have been av'd by the skilful ue of Phlebotomy, have been uffer'd to dye for want of it, upon a dilike of that Remedy that Phyicians for many Ages thought to be grounded upon no les authority than a poitive Aphorim of Hippocrates. And therefore if, to remove the pecious objection newly mention'd againt that whole kind of Remedies call'd Specificks, the following Tract has been o happy as to how, that 'tis at leat poible, that Medicines aid to be Specifick, may perform their operations by ways, which tho'
not explicable by the vulgar Doctrine of the Schools, are intelligible, and reconcileable, to the clear Principles of the Mechanical Phyloophy: If, I ay, this have been done by the Theory propos'd in this Treatie, it may conduce omewhat to inlarge the minds of many Phyicians, and invite them to make ue of everal Remedies, of which they did not think, or againt which they were prejudic'd. And ince Specificks, where they can be had, are wont to be free from any immoderate manifet quality, and for the mot part to work more benignly, as well as more effectually, caeteris paribus, than other Medicines; I think that to bring them into due requet, and invite Phyicians to earch for new ones, as well as imploy thoe already known, may tend much to horten many Cures, and make them more eay and more afe.

div.head: THE Advertiement OF THE PUBLISHER.
div.p:
THE Author had occaion to touch upon ome of the ame Subjects that he here treats of, in a Book, The Uefulnes of Experimental Philoophy, long ince publiht; but he had the misfortune to be reduc'd to write the following Dicoure about Specifick Medicines, and the Utility of Simple Remedies, in a Village where he had not that Book at hand, and could not call to mind all that he had therein publihed eventeen or eighteen
years before: On which account, though he tudiouly forbore to repeat the particulars that he remembred to have et down in that Treatie, how oppoite oever they would have been to his preent purpoe, yet having ince the following Dicoure was ent to the Pres, got a ight of that other (which he had not read in many years) he finds upon a tranient View that ome of the ame things are mentioned in both Books: at which dicovery, though he be omewhat troubled, yet he is the les o, becaue they are but few, in comparion of the new ones, and et down on uch occaions, or with uch other circumtances, that may make a favourable Reader look on them, as not bare repetitions. And tho' in the forecited Treatie, ome of the motives to make ue of imple Medicines, be lightly touch'd, yet beides, that they are not all that are mention'd in the following invitation, thoe arguments that are there but pointed at, are here treated of, and both confirm'd, and explain'd by other Obervations, and Receits. And ince the Printed Book above mention'd has been
for divers years very carce, 'tis preum'd that thoe many Readers that have it not, will not be dipleas'd to find here ome few things for which they cannot reort thither: And as the Author foreaw he might be oblig'd to conent to the tranlation of the following papers into the Roman Tongue, o he thought his Latine Readers would not repine, tho' a great number of particulars had been borrow'd of a Book that is not yet extant in their Language.

I hall give you no farther account of the particulars contain'd in the two enuing Treaties, ince the title pages give a ufficient hint of the Noble Authors main cope, and chief deign, I hall only ay, that the firt Treatie effectually performs what has not been as yet attempted by anwering a very coniderable objection againt the Doctrine of the Corpucularian Philoophers, namely, that which is taken from what we call Specifick Medicines, their vertues, and operations being hitherto judg'd by everal of the learnedet ort wholly irreconcileable to the principles of the new Philoophy;
whereby he gratifieth not only the curioity of Speculative Philoophers, but does likewie a notable piece of Service to all Phyicians, uhering in here and there uch notions as may be the Principles of a ure, and eaie Practice, yea and enable them too, to give a good account of their own Receits; I mean of thoe that contain Specifick Medicines, whoe vertues hitherto we could not decribe to our Patients, but by aying they did work we knew not how, or by ome Specifick, that is by ome occult or hidden quality. The econd Treatie, which is an Invitation to the ue of imple Medicines, is of uch a general ue, that Mankind is much indebted to this Noble Author for it, 'tis o well grounded both upon Reaon, and Experience, that this as well as the foremention'd dicoure, does fully anwer the great repute of the Author both at home, and abroad, where he is commonly til'd the Englih Phyloopher.

div.head: The Publiher thought fit to tranlate for the benefit of every common Reader, ome Latine paages contained in the foregoing Treaties.
div.p: P. 70. From the year of our Lord 1645. in the pace of fourteen years I cur'd above a thouand Frebricitants without Bleeding, Purging, or Sweating, by the help of a ingle precipitating Remedy, without any regard to the nature of the Feaver, whether it were intermittent, or continued, whether it were a Tertian, or a Quartan, which is harder to cure than any other, yea without conidering any other circumtance either of Time, Place, Sex, or Age, and that in a very hort time, without any danger of Relape, and without any coniderable trouble of the Patient, if through his own. Intemperance, he fell not into new Fits again.
Kergerus de fermentati Sect. 3. cap. 3. p. mihi 250.

P. 130. I have made my elf a frequent trial of this Stone, having carried everal of thoe little Stones tyed together about my Neck in uch a manner, that the Stones did touch the Mouth of my Stomach, yet they were beneficial, tho they had nothing graven upon 'em, &c.
Galen. de impl. med. facul. 1. 9. tit. de lap.

div.head: OF THE Reconcileablenes of Specifick Medicines, TO THE Corpucular Philoophy.
The Introduction, To my Learned Friend, Dr. F.
div.p:
PErceiving, by our late Conference, that the thing which mot alienates you, from the Corpucular Philoophy, is an Objection drawn from your own Profeion and Experience, namely, that the Specifick Vertues of Medicines
are not reconcileable to it; my unwillingnes that an Hypotheis, I am o kind to as I am to the Mechanical, hould continue under the disfavour of a Peron I o much eteem, as I do Dr. F. makes me venture to offer you the annexed Paper, thÃ´ it be but an Inlargement of a dimembred part of what I long ince, to gratify a Friend, noted about the Origine or Production of Occult Qualities. For thÃ´ I pretend not, that this Trifle hould atisfy a man of your Judgment and Learning, yet it may perhaps erve to keep you from thinking it impoible, that a skilful Pen may be able quite to urmount thoe Difficulties, that o bad a Pen as mine is capable of leening.

div.head: A Paper belonging to the writings about the Mechanical Origine of Qualities.
div.p: AMong the everal kinds of occult qualities that, which is afforded by Specifick Vertues of Medicines, is not here to be pretermitted. For thee Qualities do not only, like other hidden ones, invite, our curioity, but concern our health and may hereafter (if I mitake not) appear to be of much greater importance, than as yet they are commonly thought. However it may be worth while to take ome notice of them in this place, if it were but becaue divers Learned Phyicians do, as ome of themelves owned to me, reject or disfavour the Corpucular Philoophy upon this account, That they think it cannot be reconcil'd to the vertues of Specifick Remedies, or at leat cannot, either in a particular or in a general way, give any tolerable account of them.

I find three orts of Qualities mention'd in the Books of phyicians, under the notion of Specifick Vertues. For by ome a Medicine is aid to have a Specifick Faculty, becaue it is eminently and peculiarly friendly to this or that particular Part of the Body, as the Heart, the Brain, the Eye, &c. By others it is aid, by a Specifick Power, to attract and evacuate ome determinate Humour, as Choler, Phlegm, &c But the mot uual account, upon which a Medicine is aid to be Specifick, is that it has the vertue to cure, by ome hidden property, this or that particular dieae, as a Pleuriy, an Athma, the colick, the Dropy, &c. And this being the principal and mot common ene, in which the word Specifick is employ'd by Phyicians, I hall ordinarily make ue of it, in that ene, in the following dicoure, but yet without o confining my elf to it, as not to conider it in the two other enes, when occaion hall require.

But before I decend to particular
conidertions 'twill not be amis to obviate mitakes by declaring, in what ene in this Paper, I hall employ the Term Specifick Medicine, epecially in the lat of the three foremention'd Acceptions.

I do not then by a Specifick undertand a Medicine, that will cure the dieae it is good for Infallibly, and in all Perons that take it, for I confes I never yet met with any uch remedy. Nor do I by Specifick undertand a Medicine that, almot like a Charm, works only by ome latent and unaccountable Property, without the aitance of any known Quality, as Purgative, Diuretick, Sudorific, &c. to be found in other Medicines: But by Specifick I mean, in this dicoure, uch a medicine as very often, if not mot commonly, does very coniderably, and better than ordinary Medicines, relieve the Patient, whether by quite curing, or much leening, his dieae, and which acts principally upon the account of ome Property or peculiar vertue; o that
if it have any manifet Quality that is friendly, yet the good it does is greater, than can reaonably be acribed to the degree it has of that manifet Quality, as hot, cold, bitter, udorifick, &c.

There are two grand Quetions, that may be propos'd about the Specifick vertues acrib'd to Medicines, The firt is, whether there be really any uch, and the econd whether, if there be, the Mechanical Hypotheis can be accommodated to them.

The former of thee Quetions may admit of a double ene, for it may be propos'd with repect, either to the preent meaure of our knowledge, or to thoe further attainments that, in future times, men may arrive at.

In the latter of thee enes, (to dipatch firt the conideration of that) I hall not preume to maintain, without retriction, either part of the Quetion. For I do not only hope, but am apt to think, that in time
the Indutry and Sagacity of men will be able to dicover Intelligible caues of mot of thoe Qualities, that now pas for Occult, and among them of many of the Specifick vertues acrib'd to Medicines. And yet, on the other ide, I much fear that men will not be uccesful, in tracing out the true and immediate caues of thoe good effects of ome remedies, that depend upon uch fine and uncommon Textures, and uch latent and odly guided Motions, as fall not under our Senes, thÃ´ perhaps aited by Intruments. Which conjecture will appear the les improbable, if we conider thoe admirable Idioyncraiae, or Peculiarities of Dipoition, whereof the Books of eminent Writers afford us many intances, to whoe number I could, upon my own Obervation, add everal, if I thought it needful. And, thÃ´ I am not ignorant that ome of thee may be plauibly accounted for, as that of ome mens averion to cheee, or to cats; yet I do not think that the like explications
can be extended to ome others, that might be nam'd, if it were here pertinent to dicus that throughly.

As to the former ene, of the Quetion lately propounded, I confes my elf very amiable to the Affirmative, as far as I can judge by thoe writings of Phyicians I have had occaion to perue. Which limitation I add, becaue I would not derogate from the knowledge of particular perons, who in o learned and inquiitive an Age, may be arriv'd at far greater attainments than thoe Phyicians have done, that have entertain'd the Publick about the Occult and Specifick Qualities of Medicines.

I know there have been, and till are, Dogmatical Phyitians, that upon the Principles, as they pretend, of the School-Philoophy, reject all Medicinal vertues that they think not reducible to manifet Qualities. But of uch Galen omewhere jutly complains, that they either deny matters
of fact, or aign very incompetent caues o the effects they pretend to explain. And, for my part, I am o far from believing thee men capable of giving ufficient reaons of the more hidden Properties of Medicins, that I am not apt to think them able, by their Principles, to give clear and particular explications, even of the more eay and familiar vertues of imples.
I am therefore dipos'd to think that, in the ene formerly deliver'd of the Term Specifick Medicines, there are ome Remedies that deerve that name.

To this opinion I have been led by everal Reaons And firt (to begin with the leat weighty) it has the uffrage of many learned Phyicians, both Ancient and Modern, and particularly that of Galen himelf in everal places of his Works. And I remember that, treating of a Specifick Remedy againt the biting of a mad Dog, which vertue he acribes to an occult Quality, or, as he peaks, to
the Propriety of the whole Subtance;Galen. de Simpl. Medicam. Fac. Lib. 11. he takes occaion to promie, that he would write a Book of things that operate upon that account. Which Book, if it had cap'd with his other Works (for he elewhere cites it as having written it) would probably have furnih'd us with everal things to trengthen our opinion. And thÃ´ in Matters Philoophical I am little way'd by mere Authority, yet the concurrent uffrage, of many eminent Phyicians, may in this controvery be the more coniderable, becaue mot of them, being noted Practitioners, had opportunity to oberve whether or no any Remedies deerv'd the name of Specificks: And their Tetimony is, in our cae, the more to be regarded, becaue Phyicians, epecially famous ones, are not wont to be willing to acknowledge, that there are Effects, which fall under the Cogniance of their art, whereof they cannot give the caues.

My next Inducement, to admit
Specificks, is founded upon Parity of Reaon: For 'tis manifet, that there are divere formidable Maladies, that are produc'd by inconiderable quantities of Poyons, that have not been dicover'd to produce uch great and dimal Effects by any Manifet Quality, whether firt, econd, or third, as Medical Authors (I doubt not over accurately) ditinguih them.

On this occaion I hall add a very odd Accident, about which I was advis'd with by an expert oculit, very oon after it happen'd: The Cae was this. A man lying omewhat long in Bed in the morning, and chancing, as he lay upon his Back, to cat up his Eyes to the Teter, aw a great Spider, that tood till jut over his Face: Wherefore having reproach'd his Wife, who happen'd to be in the Room, with gros negligence, he took a Broom, and truck it upon the upper part of the Teter, to beat down the Spider; but the Animal held o fat with his Feet that he mis'd her aim, and he, whether frighted
or irritated by this rude hake, let fall upon the Man, that was taring at it to ee what would happen, a drop of Liquor that lighted directly upon one of his open Eyes. But finding no heat nor harpnes inue, but rather a very enible coldnes, he made nothing of it, but roe and put on his cloth's. But preently after, happening to rub with his finger the other Eye, he was adly urpriz'd to find himelf uddenly benighted, and calling for aitance, he found that the Eye, which the Spider had let fall omething on, thÃ´ no change were noted in it by the bytanders, was totally depriv'd of ight. Upon which core he repair'd to the above mention'd Oculits: But whether he afterwards recover'd his ight or no, I cannot tell; all the endeavours the Oculit arid I imploy'd to find out his Lodging (to which it eems he had left a wrong direction) having been Fruitles. This brought into my mind, that I had ometimes wonder'd to ee how much more quickly Spiders
will kill Flyes, than the cutting off their Heads, or running them quite through with Pins or Needles will do.

But to return to what I was aying, of the great Michief done to Humane Bodies, by very mall quantities of Poyon; methinks one may thence argue that it eems not improbable that Appropriated Medicines, epecially when adminitred in greater quantity, may produce very notable changes in the Humane Body to the advantage of it. But on this occaion I expect to be told, that 'tis much more eay to do harm, than good, and I confes 'tis o in the general, but yet, in the particular cae before us, I conider that ome Poyons, that produce uch dreadful Symptoms in the Body, are frequently cur'd by their appropriated Antidotes, which therefore mut have a Sanative Power great enough, with the help but of the ordinary Concoure of Nature, to urmount the efficacy of the venemous Matter. To which I hall add this more familiar intance
that as Perfumes do often enough produce various, and ometimes frightful, Symptoms in many Hiterical Women; o the fumes of the burnt Feathers of Patridges, Woodcocks, &c. do frequently cure the Fit in as little time as the weet mell procur'd it. And I have often found the mell of trong Spirit of Harts-horn, or Sal-Armoniac, recover uch Women in far les time, than the fragrant odours imploy'd to make them i â€¢â€¢ .

The Third and Principal Inducement I had, to think there are Specifick Remedies, is from Experience. I might urge, on this occaion, the Tetimony of Galen, who tells us more than once, that he himelf therefore confided, in the Ahes of burnt Craw-Fihes, for the cure of the biting of a Mad Dog, becaue never any of thoe that took it dy'd. And to annex that upon the by, for the uefulnes of it, he adds, that thÃ´ the effect of thee ahes be admirable,Galen. de impl. Med. Fac. lib. 11. even when
given alone, yet their vertue may be increaed, by adding to ten parts of burnt Craw Fihes five of Gentian and one of Frank-incene. And the great vertue of thee burnt Shell-fihes I find to have been taken notice of ome ages before Galen; Diocorides much commending them againt the ame Dieae that the Pergamenian does.

I hall in this place purpoely forbear to mention uch Medicines, as, thÃ´ by divers learned Phyicians commended as Specificks, are yet by others much quetion'd, if not flatly deny'd to be o. Since it may be more proper, and may perhaps uffice, to mention two or three, whoe efficacy is more notorious.

'Tis known, by almot daily experience, in Italy and divers other hot Countreys, that thÃ´ the tings of Scorpions oftentimes produce very acute Pains, and formidable Symptoms, yet the Michief is eaily remedy'd, either by preently cruhing the Body of the Scorpion upon the
Hurt, or by anointing the part affected with Oyl of Scorpions, (for that reaon to be almot every where found,) which being made by uffocating thoe Inects in common Oyl, and keeping it long in the Sun, the Liquor does not at all appear to have any manifet Quality, to which its anative Efficacy may be acribed.

The Bitings of thoe Serpents, which for the noie they are wont to make, with a kind of empty Bladders in their Tails, the Englih call Rattlenakes, are counted much more poyonous and dangerous than the tings of Scorpions. Of which I remember a learned Eye witnes, that liv'd divers years in Virginia, where they much abound, related to me a very trange Intance, which I cannot now tay to et down. And yet the Englih Planters, when they have the mifortune to be bitten by thee Serpents, are wont to cure themelves very happily by the ue of that plant, which from its effects, and the place it grows
in, is well known by the name of Virginian Snakeweed, [or Serpentaria Virginiana.

That the Peruvian Bark, commonly call'd here in England the Jeuits Powder, is a Specifick againt Agues, particularly Quartans, divers learned Phyicians not only grant but aert. And I remember the jutly famous Dt. Willis gave me this Character of it in private dicoure, (not without taking notice that ome decry'd it,) 'Tis the noblet Medicine we (meaning the Phyicians) know. But thÃ´ I will not dipute, whether it be o certain and afe a Specifick for Agues, as 'tis believ'd by, divers eminent Doctors, yet I think it can carce be deny'd, to be a Specifick Medicine to top the fits of Agues, (in the notion of Specifick Remedies formerly deliver'd) ince it does that far more effectually, than the generality of Phyicians, for many ages, were wont to do, with their other Antifebrile Medicines.

I might here tell you, that I have
my elf een a tone, whoe efficacy in topping Hemorrhagies invited my Wonder; and another, which perform'd extraordinary things in more than one Ditemper thÃ´ I could not perceive that either of them did thee things by any manifet Quality. And I might here add ome other particulars, that may be borrow'd from Experience, in favour of our opinion, but that 'tis like they will be more properly alledg'd hereafter in ome places of the remaining Part of our Dicoure.

I know thoe, that have rejected Specifick Medicines, have confidently urg'd three plauible Arguments againt them. For ome Phyicians deny there are any Effects of Medicines o coniderable, as to make them deerve the name of Specifick. Others would probably allow that Experience favours our opinion, if they did not think the way of a Specifick Medicines operating mut be inexplicable, and conequently ought not be admitted by Phyicians. And others
again (being of Sentiments very differing from thee) will allow them to be very efficacious, but endeavour to derive their whole Efficacy from Manifet Qualities, as heat, cold, tenuity of Parts, faculty of making large Evacuations by Vomit, Siege, &c.

But thee objections will be more opportunely conider'd in due places, Only there is one Argument, that may be objected by the deniers of Specifick remedies, which I confes is o pecious, as to deerve to be particularly examin'd in this place, let it hould, if unremov'd, beget too trong a prejudice againt a great part of the enuing Dicoure. For it may be aid, that a Medicine taken in at the Mouth mut, in the Stomach and Guts, be at let very much chang'd by Digetion, and the Aliments it meets with there, and a good Part of it will be procrib'd among excrements. That alter it has pas'd out of the Stomach, it mut meet with divers trainers of differing Textures, which will probably top all or mot of the
Medicinal Corpucles that would pervade them. And that if any hal be o lucky, or o penetrating, as to urmount all thee obtacles, they will probably either be aimilated unto the Subtance of the Body, or quite chang'd by the parts they will be fain to combine with there. Or, if yet any hould be able o obtinately to retain their pritine Nature, they will in all likely hood be too few to have any coniderable operation upon the Body. But to this plauible objection I have everal things to oppoe by way of Anwer.

1. And firt I may repreent, that divers Specifick Medicines, as ome ome Oyntments, Plaiters, Poultis's Amulets, Pericarpia, &c. Being outwardly apply'd, their Corpucles can get into the Mas of Blood without paing through the Stomach, and conequently are not concern'd in the propos'd objection.

2. Againt mot of the Galenical Phyicians, that are wont to urge
the formerly propos'd objection, I ee not why one may not argue ad hominem by putting them in mind, that the ame Difficulties for the main, or others not inferior, may be alledged againt a common opinion of their own. For ince they believe that Purgatives, Cordials, Diaphoreticks, beides Cephalicks, Hepaticks, and ome other orts of Medicines, do contemperate, and weeten the Blood, and uefully affect the newly mentioned table Parts; and ince thee Medicines act not by naked Qualities but by mall Particles, of their own ubtance, if they can give us an intelligible account of the ingres of thee Particles in coniderable numbers, into the Recees of the Body, without being, dipoyl'd of their particular virtues, they will at the ame time intruct us, how to anwer the objection they urge againt us.

3. And in regard the generality of Phyicians hold, that Milk, and Urine, were materially in the Mas
of Blood, and are eparated from it by the Breats, and Kidneys; I think one may by experience hew she invalidity of their ratiocination againt Specificks. For 'tis obvious to oberve, and I have everal times done it my elf, that Rubarb will (perhaps for many hours) tinge the Urine of thoe that take any coniderable doe of it And in ome of our Englih American Colonies, there grows a fruit, which the planters call the Prickled Pear, whoe inward Subtance is exceeding red, and whoe being pleaant in tat, as well as colour, frequently invites eaters; but its Juice is of o penetrating a nature, that it paes from the tomach into the Bladder, and then into the chamberpot, with o little los of its rednes, that trangers are wont to be urpris'd and frighted at it, as thinking this unknown fruit had made them void bloody Urine, if not blood rather than Urine. This is a known thing among thoe, that have dwelt in our Southern Plantations, and has
been affirm'd to me by unupected Eye-witnees, and among them by a famous Phyician. As for Milk, the great Hippocrates himelf informs us, that if a Woman, or a he-goat take Elaterium, the Cathartick vertue paes into the Milk, and will purge the Child that drinks it. And I remember that haying occaion to make ome tay, in the Spring or beginning of Summer, in the confines of Switzerland and Savoy, I had the opportunity to oberve this odd Phaenomenon, That when the Cows, in that Ditrict, fed, as they would in that eaon plentifully do, upon a certain weed, aid to be a kind of Wild-Garlick, that grew copiouly in the Patures, the very Butter made of their Milk had o rank a tat of the Herb, that though I was not, yet divers other trangers were, thereby diverted from eating of it, though otherwie freh and good. And I remember too, that having pas'd a Winter on the Seacoat of the County of Cork in Ireland, I found it a known obervation,
that a ort of greedy Sea-fowl, whoe name comes not now into my mind, living almot wholly upon Fih, (upon whoe choles I have ometimes wondered to ee uch a multitude of ravenous Fowls attending) they acquire a Tat that makes ome pleaantly Quetion, whether the food they afford be to be reputed fleh or fih. But how contantly the Particles of divers Bodies may retain their nature in all the digetion, and trainers they pas through, I have more amply dicours'd in another Tract, About the concealments and diguies of eminal Principles. And I preume I have here aid enough, to allow me to proceed to the fourth part of my anwer.

4. I conider then, in the lat place, that whereas 'tis objected, that o mall a quantity of the matter of a Specifick, as is able to retain its nature when it arrives at the part it hould work on, mut have little or no power left to relieve it. This difficulty will not much tagger thoe
that know, how unafe it is to meaure the power that natural Agents may have, to work upon uch an engine as the Humane Body, by their bulk rather than by their ubtilty and and activity A ober Gentleman, that was Governour of a Colony in the Torrid one, and commanded a Warlike Englih Veel, that ail'd up very far in the great River of Gambia or Gambra in Africk, and taid there ome time to trade with the Negro's of the Inland Countrey, being inquired of by me, among other things, about the Poyons that are aid to be extraordinarily powerful in the Parts he came from; he anwered me, that the Blacks had a Poyon, that was, though omewhat low, yet very mortal; in o mall a doe, that it was uual for them to hide enough of it to kill a man, under one of their Nails, which they wear omewhat long: Whence they would drop it o dextrously into the Drink, or Milk, or Broth or other Liquid Aliment of thoe they ow a pite to, that 'tis carce
poible for a tranger to be watchful enough to prevent it. For which reaon, as he told me, though he ometimes eat with their petty Princes, or Governours, at the ame table, yet he would never eat out of the ame dih, nor drink out of the ame Cups with any of them. He added that, in another part of Africa, a famous Knight, who commanded the Englih there, and lately died a hip-board in his way home, was o poyoned at a parting Treat, by a young Negro Woman of Quality, whom he had enjoy'd and declin'd to take with him, according to his promie, into Europe. And though my Relator early gave him notice of what he upected to be the caue of this Indipoition, and engag'd him thereupon to take Antidotes, and Cordials, as Treacle, &c. yet his languihing ditemper till increaed, till it kill'd him.

I could name a Vegetable Subtance, growing in Europe, and perhaps not far from hence, which though ome Empiricks employ as a Medicine, is
o violently, operative, that a Learned and famous Modern Phyitian relates, that no more than half a grain would work o violently, as to caue very dangerous Hypercathares, of which though he remedy'd ome, yet he was not able to keep all from being Mortal. And becaue many ingenious men deny that out Englih Vipers are poyonous, I hall add in favour of the Argument that I have been enforcing that I know a Young man, who having been bitten by an Englih Viper, which he too rahly laid hold on, though the tooth pricked but his hand, yet the venom, convey'd by o mall a hurt which perhaps equal'd not in quantity the hundredth part of Pins head, quickly produc'd in him the bad Symptoms that uually follow the Biteing of that Serpent,; And among others (for I particularly ask'd him about that) a violent vomiting of ill condition'd tuff. I know alo a peron, that practis'd Phyick in the Ile of Iava, where Scorpions are held to be more
venemous than in Italy who having, after he had drank ome what freely, provok'd, and bin tung by, a Scorpion, thÃ´ the Hurt was but in his Thumb, and was o mall that I could not perceive the leat car it had left, that it put him preently to uch violent tortures, for ome hours, till he had procur'd Specifick remedies, that he look'd upon himelf a dead man; and felt o raging a heat within that he thought (to ue his own Expreion) that hellfire was got into his Body. Nor is it only by mere poyons, that a Humane Body may be greatly affected, thÃ´ the agent be but very inconiderable for bulk and weight, for we ee, that divers Women, otherwie trong and healthy, will be cat into ounding fits, and perhaps will complain of uffocation, and be put into convulive Motions, by the fragrant Odours of Musk, or Civet; though if all the Effluvia, that caue thee Symptomes, were reduc'd into one aggregate, this would not probably amount to a hundredth, nor perhaps to a thouandth,
part of a grain. And I have oftentimes peedily uppres'd uch fits, by the odour of the volatile Salts Harts-horn, Sal Armoniac, or the like, or of detill'd Spirits abounding with uch Salts; though perhaps all the Particles, that actually relieved the patient, and calm'd thee frightful Symptoms, if pack'd together, would not have equal'd, either in bignes or in weight, the tenth, not to ay the fifteenth, or the hundredth, part of a grain of mutard-eed. And as for inward remedies, 'tis vulgarly known, that in the infuion of Crocus Metallorum, Corpucles that render the Liquor vehemently vomitive and Purgative, are o very minute, that great proportions of Wine, or other Vehicles may be trongly impregnated with them without any enible diminution of the Body that parts with them. And of this we have a not les, if not more, coniderable intance, when Quick-Silver is decocted or long infus'd in common Water. For Helmont oberves that,
though the Liquor be not altered in Colour, or Tat, nor the Quick-ilver at all enibly chang'd, nay nor grown any thing lighter in a ballance, yet the Liquor does, by means of thee inenible and unponderable Effluxes of the Quickilver, acquire a notable virtue againt worms; for which purpose not only Helmont, but before him that experienc'd Chymit Hartman, and another eminent Writer, extoll this Medicine. And on this occaion I remember that a fine Boy, born to be heir to a very illutrious family, falling into a dangerous Feaver, which was judg'd to proceed from worms or verminous matter; a famous and Experienc'd Phyitian, that treated him, confes'd to me, that he was out of hopes of him; Becaue the Child, having been bred to have his will, and tir'd with unuccesful Remedies, was o obtinate and carefull in refuing to take any thing, that meld or relih'd of a Medicine, that he forbore, in pite of all the art u'd to deceive him, even to drink
any thing but mall Beer Whereupon I perwaded both the Doctor, and the Lord, whoe on the child was, to impregnate his mall beer with Mercurial particles, by frequently haking it with good Quick-ilver in it. By which means the patient, perceiving no change of Colour or Tat in the Drink, wallow'd it greedily, and through the bleing of God was oon after retor'd to a Health, which the Parties concern'd acrib'd to the Mercurial remedy.

I hould condemn my elf, for having betowed o many words upon one objection, but that I hope the Anwer, given to it in this place, will facilitate and hortens everal things relating to my preent Subject Specifick Medicines. About which I hall now proceed to offer my thougths in ome Propoitions, and hort dicoures upon them.

Having now dipatch'd the firt of the two formerly propos'd Inquiries, I proceed to the econd, namely, whether the Mechanical Hypotheis
can be accommodated to Specifick Medicines, o as that they may be either intelligibly explicated by a, or at leat hown to be reconcilable to it. I preume you will eaily believe, that there are few writers more inclinable, than I'am, to confes the dimnes of our knowledge, and the obcurity of many things in nature; or that are more forward than I to grant, that many of the operations, of Specifick Medicines, are to be reckoned among thoe abtrue things, whereof nature eems to affect the concealment. But notwithtanding this, when I conider how comprehenive and fertile the principles of the Corpucular Philoophy are, I cannot depair bur that it will be found, that divers of the effects of thee Medicines may be, in a general way explicated by them, and not any will appear inconitent with them. This I deire may be here taken notice of once for all that, retaining the Scope of the following dicoure till in your memory, you may not think
it trange, that I content my elf, on mot occaions, to give in general poible explications, and to hew that Specifick Medicines may operate on ome uch account as I propoe, without affirming that they certainly do o I oberv'd oon after the beginning of this Paper that there were three orts of virtues to which Phyicians (thÃ´ not unanimouly) have given this Title of Specifick; namely uch as evacuate ome particular humour, uch as are peculiarly friendly to this or that part of the Humane Body, and uch as in an unknown way cure or much leen this or that determinate Dieae. But yet I hall now apply my dicoure peculiarly to the lat ort of thee Medicines, as being both more coniderable in it elf and the chief ubject intended in preent Dicoure, giving nevertheles, as occaion erves, uch additional Hints and obervations, as may make the Reflections, belonging to this Third ort of Specificks, eaily applicable Mutatis Mutandis to the other two.

And I hall begin with laying here for a foundation what I have in another Treatie had occaion to deliver and make out, namely, That a living Humane Body is not to be look'd upon as a mere tatue, or a mere Congeries of the Materials 'tis compos'd of, Fleh, Blood, Bones, Fat, Nerves, Veins, Arteries, &c. But an admirably fram'd Engine, coniting of Stable, Liquid, and Pneumatick Subtances, o exquiitely adapted to their repective functions and Ues, that oftentimes the effects of an agent upon it are not to be meaured o much by the power of that agent conidered in it elf, as by the effects that are conequently produc'd by the action of the parts of the Living Engine it elf upon one another.

This premis'd, I conider that there is no need to grant that the operations of all Specificks, or of the ame in differing Dieaes, mut be of one kind; but that differing Specificks may operate in everal manners, and ome by one of thee ways may oppugn
uch a dieae, and others may do good againt uch another. And of thee general ways I hall briefly propoe ix or even that now occur to my thoughts. For having firt given you this important caution, that the Specifick Remedy do's not commonly (though ometimes it may) relieve the patient by this or that ingle way of operating, but by a concurrence of two or more, that as it were joyn their forces to produce the deired effect.

div.head: PROPOSITION. I.
div.p: And firt, ometimes the Specifick Medicine may cure by dicuing, or reolving the morbifick matter, and thereby making it fit for expulion by the greater common hores of the Body, and the Pores of the skin.

'Tis known that many Dieaes, and thoe oftentimes tubborn and Chronical, proceed from certain tough or vicous Humours, that obtruct the paages wereby the blood hould
circulate, or other uefull Liquors be tranmitted. And thee peccant Humours are oftentimes o vicid and obtinate, that ordinary Remedies will do little or no good upon them. And yet a Specifick may, by the malnes, and congruous Figure of ome of its Corpucles, get through the Pores into the Recees of this tubborn matter; and by their olidity, Figure, and Agitation, promoted by the heat of the patients Body, may diolve and ruine the texture of the Morbifick matter, and render it capable of being procribed by nature, by Urine, Sweat, or ome other commodious and innocent Evacuation. Thus the blood, or ome other Liquor of the Body, being (to ue the Chymits Phrae) impregnated with the friendly and operative Particles of the Remedy, becomes an appropriated Mentruum in referrence to the Pecant matter: impregnated with Sal Armoniack becomes a Mentruum, that by degrees will diolve both Copper and Iron, as compact bodies as they are. I aid appropriated Mentruum, becaue
there is no ufficient reaon to uppoe, that the Mentruum works by any manifet quality, as Heat Moiture, &c. or even by Acidity it elf: But rather by virtue of the fitnes, which the hape, bulk, olidilty, and other Mechanical affections of its particles, concur to give it, to disjoyn the parts of a body of uch a determinate Texture. For as I have in another Paper amply hewn, there are far more Mentruums of ditinct orts than are commonly taken notice of, and the operations of thee cannot afely be meaured by the trength of their manifet qualities, ince it may everal times happen, that a Mentruum, les acid or les trongly tated, may diolve this or that body, which another Mentruum, that eems far tronger, will not work on. Thus cold water will diolve the white of an Egg, which pure pirit of wine will be o far from diolving, that it will coagulate it; [and o will pirit of Salt and Oyl of Vitriol it elf.] Thus dephlegm'd pirit of Urine
will readily diolve minute filings of Copper, which pirit of Vinegar will but lowly work upon; and yet this Liquor will peedily diolve Crabs Eyes, which pirit of Urine will leave entire. Thus Quickilver, that is inipid, will in the cold diolve Gold, which Aqua Fortis it elf, though aited by exeternal heat will not work upon; and yet Aqua Fortis will furiouly bear aunder the parts of Iron, though Quickilver will not o much as adhere to its urface. And thus in fine (not to accumulate intances) common Oyl, that is o mooth upon the Tongue, and will not diolve o much as an Egg-hell, will diolve Brimtone, which yet will reit Aqua Fortis it elf, that will diolve almot all Metals, beide many hard Stones and Minerals. And I know a liquor, having more than once prepar'd it, which, though o weak that one may drink a Wine Glas full of it pure without danger, will yet work on ome very hard bodies, both Stones &
Metals, in a way that is not to be matched, among the highly corroive Mentruums in ue among Chymits.

And now, uppoing that the active Corpucles, of a pecifick Medicineaociated with the blood, or other Vehicle they impregnate, may act upon the morbifick matters they meet with in the body, after the manner of Mentruum; uppoing this I ay, we may hence illutrate everal things that have reference to the operation of pecifick Medicines.

1. And we may hence derive a Gues, why an appropriated Medicine will perform things, which will not be done by another, whoe manifet qualities eem to be the ame for kind, and much tronger in degree. For Mentruums do not always act according to the degree of their Acidity, or the like enible quality, but according to the congruity of their Corpucles to the pores of the body they are to diolve; and alo oftentimes according to a fitnes that depends upon other Mechanical Affections
of the acting Liquor. And therefore Phyicians, as well as others, may eaily mitake in their Argumentations Ã majori ad minus, & Ã minori ad majus. For the conequence is not good to argue either thus, Water, which is o trengthles Liquor, will diolve Gum Arabic, therefore highly rectified pirit of Wine, which is a much more ubtil and penetrateing Liquor, will doe the ame thing more powerfully; for Experience hews, it will not diolve it at all: or thus, trong Oyl of Vitriol is more corroive in tate, and will diolve many bodies that Aqua Fortis will not, therefore it will alo diolve Silver as well as Aqua Fortis, the contrary of which is true. Nay 'tis not a good inference to argue thus, Aqua Fortis is diolves Silver by virtue of its acid Spirits, therefore the more it abounds with thee, the more potently it will diolve that Metal, whereas I have elewhere prov'd by Experience, that if Aqua Fortis be made exceeding trong, it will not
work upon Silver, but it will readily do it if it be weakned by the addition of a fit quantity of Common Water.
To this I hall add, that the diolution of a Body may depend, as well upon the peculiar texture of the body it elf, as the manifet trength of the Mentruum.

2ly. The foregoing Doctrine may ugget a Reaon, why a Medicine that does wonders in one dieae, may do little or nothing in another, that ome may think to be a kin to it, and perhaps too, more eaily uperable by it. For the preum'd cognation may not be o great, but that ome diimilitude of texture in the morbifick matters, may make one of them unfit to be wrought upon by the ame Mentruum that dioloves the other. And though pure Spirit of Wine will eaily enough diolve Gummi Guajacum, and alo the little portion of reinous matter that are harbour'd in the Pores and mall cavities of the Wood; yet the ame Mentruum will
not work upon the Wood it elf of the Tree that affords thoe oluble Subtances.

3. This may keep it from being thought trange, that Specifick Medicines hould ometimes fail of their uual Effects. For, as the Bodies of individual Patients, may differ very much, either according to their natural Contitution, or to that which they acquire by the dieae that ditempers them, or on both thoe accounts; So it ought not to eem trange, that in ome ick Perons among many, the congruity between the agent ct patient hould be alter'd, either by ome coniderable change in the Texture of the Morbifick matter, or by ome notable alteration that the Corpucles of the Medicine receive in their paage through the Veels, by the admixture of ome incongruous Particles of the Blood or other Vehicle. Thus Spirit of Salt will, as I have try'd, diolve Copper, as Spirit of Niter does: which notwithtanding, thÃ´ this lat nam'd Liquor will diolve Silver,
yet if you mix with it Spirit of Salt, which by the like operation of both upon Copper, eems to be amicable to it, the Spirit of Niter will no more be able to diolve Silver, as it could before.

4thly. Our Hypotheis may alo hint to us an anwer to one of the main and mot plauible objections of the deniers of Specifick Medicines. For ome of them ask in a Scornful way, how 'tis poible that a Medicine hould rove up and down in the Mas of Blood, and neglecting all other things, hould ingle out, and faten upon the Morbifick matter men wih it hould procribe. For if the Medicine acts by impregnating the Blood, or ome other Liquor of the Body, and turning it into a kind of Mentruum, 'tis very poible, both that the trainers through which the Corpucles mut pas, may keep back the inconvenient parts of the vehicle, and (which is in our cae more coniderable) the Mentruum may be either appropriated to the peccant Humour,
as has been formerly declar'd, or ele may at leat be qualify'd, to reolve that more eaily than any other Subtance it meets with in the Body. As if you take ome Bone-ahes, and Crocus Martis, and Saw-dut, and powdered Sea-Salt, and Filings of Gold, and blend all thee together, if upon one half of this mixture you pour common Water, it will not meddle with any other of the Ingredients except the Sea-Salt, which it will readily diolve: & if upon the other half of the ame mixture, you put a ufficient quantity of Quick-ilver, and rub them together, this Metalline Liquor will neglect all the ret of the Ingredients, and the Sea Salt it elf, and faten upon the Gold. And thoe that work in the Spanih Gold mines inform us, that when they have well ground ome Ore, that contains Gold and Copper, beides Heterogeneous Minerals, well heated Quick-ilver will take up the Gold much ooner and better than it will the Copper, carce meddling with the latter, as long
as there remains any not depicable quantity of the former, to be wrought upon by it. And as for the uppoed difficulty, that the Medicine hould Ferret out, if I may o peak, the morbifick matter, in what veel oever of the Body it lies, this objection might have been coniderable, before the dicovery of the Bloods circulation: But 'tis not o now that we know, that things that once get into the Mas of Blood, are preently whirl'd about with it, and may be convey'd by it even to mall veels lying in the remotet Parts of the Body.

5thly. And this prompts me to take notice, that our Hypotheis may help us to anwer thoe many learned Phyicians, that either reject, or at leat depie, mot External remedies, epecially Pericarpia, Amulets, and Appena, upon a uppoition, both that they neither can furnih the Body they do but externally touch, with any tore of Medicinal Particles; and which is chiefly in this place to be
conider'd, that being but external remedies, they mut be very unable to do good in Internal dieaes, epecially uch as are eated in Parts, remote from thoe which the Medicine is apply'd to. But as to the former part of the objection, 'twill not be difficult to anwer it to him that has read what I have elewhere written of the ubtility, numerounes and efficacy of Effluviums. And we need but conider, what plenty of Particles enible to the notrils, are for a long time emitted by a mall quantity of Amber-greece, or even of Camphire (which is often externally us'd) and the multitude of Magnetical Corpucles, that for many years contantly effluviate from a mall vigorous Load-tone, to think it poible that even dry and table Bodies may afford ufficient tore of effluvia, to perform coniderable things in o curiouly fram'd an Engine, as the Humane Body is; where we ee that the odour of Musk, or Civet, for intance, may peedily cat divers Perons into Fits, and the mell
of Cator or Aa faetida, and much more that of Salt of Harts-horn or of Sal Armoniack, quickly relieve them. And as to the Second Part of the objection, what I have elewhere made out, and the bet Modern Phyicians grant,The Eay of the Poroity of Animal Bodies. of the Poroity of the Skin, hows, that 'tis very poible for the ubtil Effluvia of everal Bodies, to get through the Pores of the Skin; and when they have once got admittance, o much as into the maller Veels, 'tis eaie to conceive how thee may carry them into the greater, and conequently into the Mas of Blood, by whoe Circulation they may be readily conveyed to all the Parts of the Body, and among them to the eat of the dieae: & perhaps, (to add that upon the by,) the efficacy of thee Corpucles, that, if I may o peak, get in at the Key-hole, not at the Door, may be the more considerable, becaue they get preently into the Mas of Blood, without paing thrÃ´ thoe
Digetions in the tomach and other Parts, which oftentimes much weaken the vertue of Medicines taken in at the Mouth, before they arrive at the Blood.

div.head: PROPOSITION. II.
div.p: Sometimes a Specifick Medicine may mortify the over Acid, or other immoderate Particles that infet the Mas of Blood, and detroy their coagulatory or other effects.

ThÃ´ I am not of their opinion, who of late are wont to impute almot all Dieaes to acidity, abounding in the Blood and other Liquors of the Body, by whoe intervention the table parts alo are offended; yet I readily grant that a coniderable number of Ditempers are, at leat in great part, produc'd either by Acids themelves, or by their bad effects or Productions. Agreeably to which Doctrine we may very probably conceive, that everal Maladies may be either quite
cur'd, or much leen'd, by a Specifick Remedy that abounds in Corpucles fitted to mortify Acids. This mortification may be effected by more than one way, and of thee wayes the chief that now occur to my thoughts, are two.

For there are ome Bodies, that mortify or diable Acids by a poitive Hotility, if I may o term it; that is, by uch a contrariety as is dicernable by the Tat, and more by the viible conflict, and manifet Tumult, that is produc'd, when they come to invade an Acid. Of this ort of mortifiers of Acids, are the mot part of thoe that are call'd Alcaliate Salts. Whether fixt, as the Lixivial Salts of Plants, or volatile, as the Spirits and acending Salts of Urine, Blood, Harts-horn, Soot, &c. As may be exemplify'd, when any of thee comes to be mingled with Aqua fortis, Spirit of Salt, Oyl of Vitriol, or the like Acid Liquors, by which by the way we may ee, that thoe Galenits mitake, who acribe the vertues of Spirit of Harts-horn,
and of Urine, only to their tenuity of Parts, Brisknes of Motion, and the like affections, that they might not eem beholding to the Chymits for o ueful a notion, as that of the contrariety of Acids and Alcalies.

The other principal way, by which Acids may be mortifi'd, or diabled to bite, is by Sheathing them, if I may o expres it. For as a knife may be diabled to cut, either by filing off or otherwie blunting its Edge, or ele by covering the Blade with a heath fit for it, or by ticking it into a Loaf of Bread, or the like Body fit to receive and detain the whole Blade; o an Acid Corpucle may loe its power of cutting or pricking, either by having its Figure poil'd by the action of a trong and manifet Alcaly, or ele by being as it were heath'd in a Porous Body, thÃ´ perhaps endow'd with no Tat, or any other manifet Quality, by which one would think it contrary to the Acid it diables, as a file is to the edge of a knife.
Of this way of mortifying Acids, Chymical operations afford us many intances, as when Menium detroyes the Acidity of Spirit of Vinegar, as I have found Chalk will do that of Aqua Fortis it elf; and Lapis Calaminaris very much leens, as well as alters, the Acidity of Spirit of Salt, and even of Spirit of Niter. And I the rather mention this Mineral, both becaue its Qualities are les known to Phyicians, and the generality of Chymits, and becaue it upplies me with an Argument to prove that Acids may be, thÃ´ I do not think they alwayes are, rather heath'd in, than detroy'd by the Bodies that ilently mortify them. For, as Glauber has truly enough oberved, Acid Spirits (as I have try'd in ome) may by force of fire be driven in Ditillation out of the Lapis Calaminaris, very much dephlegm'd, and tronger than before.

I know it may be here objected, that the Mortification of Acids is perform'd
by a manifet Quality, and therefore makes nothing for the feavourers of Specifick Medicines. But to this I anwer.

1. That the power of mortifying Acids, epecially by heathing them, or if you pleae, by Aborption of them, is none of thoe Qualities, whether Firt, Second or Third, that the former Phyicians took notice of in Medicines; thÃ´ the ufficiency of thee Qualities to cure dieaes, has been, and till is, us'd by many as a ground of denying the Specifick vertues of remedies.

2. That I have often look'd upon it as an happy mitake, and of ill conequence, that o many learned modern Phyicians take it for granted, that if a Medicine be endow'd with a manifet Quality, as Acid or Alcaliate, the good it does, (and the like for the mot part may be aid of the Harm) may afely be abcrib'd to that Quality, that is to its being of an Acid, or ele of an Alcaliate nature; whereas in my poor Judgment, there
being a coniderable diparity, as various Tryals have aur'd me, between Acid and Acid, as likewie between Alcaly aud Alcaly, 'tis fit to ditinguih betwixt an Acid for intance, as meerly uch, and the peculiar modification that may belong to that Acid. Thus, thÃ´ all Acid Mentruums that I know of, if they be well dephlegm'd, will diolve Copper, yet Aqua Regis that will diolve not only that Metal, but the much more cloely compacted body of Gold, will not at all diolve Silver; as on the other ide Aqua Fortis, as corroive a Mentruum as it is, will not of it elf diolve Gold, but if you give it a new Modification, by adding to it common Spirit of Salt, which it elf I have often found (whatever Chymits think or have written to the contrary) will leave it entire, the Aqua Fortis will eaily diolve that Metal. Nay a different Modification may not only make a Diparity between Acid, but that which according to the receiv'd way of Judging, ought to be call'd a contrariety:
for Spirit of Salt will precipitate Silver, which Aqua Fortis has diolv'd, and Spirit of Niter, thÃ´ one of the Acidet Mentruums we have, will not only precipitate an Antimonical powder out of that odd ubtance, that Chymits call Butter of Antimony, but will do it with a wonderful conflict, tumult, and efferveence; and yet this Butter of Antimony is o highly Acid, that a little quantity of it, put into a coniderable one of Water, makes it o our, that many Chymits call it Acetum Philoophorum. And now to apply thee things to the lately propos'd objection, I deire it may be remembred, that near the beginning of this Letter I plainly intimated to you, that I did not deny, but that a Specifick Medicine may ometimes be accompany'd with, or even in part operate by a manifet quality, but that yet I thought the good effect was not due, barely to the kind or degree of the manifet Quality, but to omewhat uperadded which gave it a Specifick vertue,
againt this or that particular Dieae. And uitably to this it may be aid, that, as there are everal kinds of Acids, and of Alcalies too, 'tis not every Acid that will be mortifi'd by every Alcaly; and have its Effects detroy'd by it, which may be illutrated by this, that, thÃ´ when Copper is diolved in Aqua Fortis 'tis poible, by the help of meer Chalk skilfully apply'd to make the Mentruum let go the Corpucles of the Metal, yet if upon uch a high colour'd olution of Copper, you hall pour (as to convince ome ingenious men, I have purpoely done a due quantity of Spirit of Urine, or the like volatile Alcaly, thÃ´ there will preently enue a great conflict and manifet ebullition, with noie and tore of Bubbles, yet between thee Hotile Salts, a multitude of the Acid Corpucles of the Aqua Fortis will not be o mortified, as to let go the Metal, but the olution varying its colour, will have and keep a deeper one than before.

And when I conider the differences
that a Skilful Oberver may find, between Vinegar, Alum, Crytals of Tartar, Juice of Lemmons, Juice of Barbaries, the eential Salts (as Chymits call them) of thoe Plants that are our in Tat, to omit divers other Acids, I am apt to think, that diorder'd nature may have, in a dieaed Body, produc'd Acids of everal orts which are not particularly known to us, and that ome of thee may be of uch a nature, that none of our common Alcalies, as uch, is able to mortify them, and which yet may be mortify'd, at leat by the way of Sheathing, by ome appropriated or peculiarly modify'd Corpucles of a Specifick Remedy which may be illutrated by what is elewhere oberv'd, that, thÃ´ neither Spirit of Vinegar, nor Spirit of Salt, nor Oyl of Vitriol it elf, would, as far as I have try'd, diolve a tone taken out of a mans Body, yet Spirit of Niter, (which does not diolve everal Podies, that I have found dioluble in Oyl of Vitriol)
will readily work upon it, and thereby loe, its Corroivenes.
Before I leave this Subject, 'twill not be amis to intimare a couple of things, that perhaps you will not think impertinent to it.

One of thee is, that, whereas I not long ago ditinctly nam'd Acids themelves and their Productions, I did it (not out of Inadvertence, but) becaue I think Preternatural Acids do not only diaffect the Body whilet they continue enibly Acid, but may in divers caes be the caues of ome Ditempers, whereof mot men would think them more likely to be the remedies. For, thÃ´ Acids be reputed to have an Inciive and Reolutive vertue, and therefore Oxymel and ome other Acetous Medicines are commended to cut tough Phlegm, and Spirit of Vitriol is us'd for the ame purpoe, and to diolve coagulated Blood; Yet, as I am willing to grant this vertue unto Acids in ome caes, o there are others wherein I much
upect, that obtructions, and conequently the dieaes that uually attend obtinate ones, may be occaion'd by Acids, as they coagulate ome Fluids in the Mas of Blood, that are dipos'd to be thicken'd by them, and by that conitence made unfit to pas with the ret of the circulating Blood, through the maller Veels and trainers of the Body, where upon that account they make obtructions. This I hall exemplify by the coagulation that I have made by ome Acid Salts, as Spirit of Salt, of the White of an Egg, epecially if by beating reduc'd to an Aqueous Conitence. And the like coagulation may eaily be effected in Milk, which may not only be peedily curdl'd with Spirit of Salt, but, as is known by Bodies not Chymically prepar'd, as Rennet and Juice of Lemons. And Experiments purpoely made have hown, that, if ome Acids be convey'd immediately into the Mas of Blood, they will coagulate even that Liquor, whilt it continues
in the Veels of the yet living Animals.

The other thing I lately told you, I was to oberve, is, that, thÃ´ Acid Corpucles are thoe, that modern Phyicians and Chymits are wont to take notice of as hurtful, both in the Blood and table Parts of the Body, except the Stomach, and perhaps ome few neighbouring Parts, as the Spleen and Pancres. And, thÃ´ ome ingenious men proceed o far, as to impute almot all Dieaes to the bad Effects of Acids, yet I am very inclinable to think, that divers maladies and ttoubleom Symptoms proceed from Corpucles, that, whether they be of a Saline nature or not, are different from Acids properly o call'd. For I conider, that there may be many Bodie, which may as 'twere reult from the combination of Acids with other Saline Particles, that much alter their nature, as I have elewhere noted, that Spirit of Salt will, with Spirit of Urine, compoe a kind of Sal-Armoniac; and Spirit of Niter with Salt of
Tartar diolv'd in common Water, will concoagulate with it into Salt Petre (or a Body exceeding like it,) and the ame Spirit of Niter or Aqua Fortis with Spirit of Urine, or of Blood, or the like, will afford a very fuible Salt, differing enough from what either of the Ingredients was before their conjunction. And 'tis vulgarly known, that Oyl of Vitriol, and Oyl of Tartar per deliquium, do by their coalition produce Tartarum Vitriolatum, in which the Acidity of the former, and the Alcaliatenes of the latter, are very much infring'd, a third Body being by reultancy produc'd, that differs much both from the former and the latter Oyl, or rather Saline Liquor. And when, beides Intances of this nature, I conider how many differing orts of Corpucles o fruitful a Principle as nature may have form'd, that, without being Acid, may yet have notable and hurtful Effects upon the Blood, or ome particular olid part of the Body. It eems probable to me, that there
may be other Qualities requir'd, to mortify or diable thee Morbifick Corpucles, than a contrariety to Acid Salts, and conequently, that a Medicine that affords Corpucles peculiarly fitted to correct or enervate this particular ort of hurtful ones, may deerve the name of a Specifick.

And here I further conider, that, as in the Body there may be divers coagulations made by Saline Corpucles manifetly Acid; o there may be others produc'd by Corpucles, Whether Saline in tat or no, that are not manifetly Acid, but perhaps rather of a contrary nature, which obervation, being wont to be overlook'd by Phyicians, and yet in my opinion of no mall importance, may deerve to be a little the more carefully made out. I have ometimes for curioity made a Liquor, that was not in Tat either Acid or Urinous; to which having put a moderate proportion of a ditill'd Liquor, which it elf was not in tat either
Acid, or Urinous, or lixiviate, it would in a very hort time, perhaps in not many minutes, be coagulated into o conitent a Body, that, thÃ´ the wide mouth'd Veel were held with the Orifice downwards, nothing would fall out of it.

I have taught in another (unpublih'd Paper, that if upon a certain olution (which I there how how to make) one drop ome Spirit of Urine, or anorhet Volatile Alcaly, there will preently be produc'd a Gelly, whoe conitence and colour may make it eaily be taken for common Starch, ready to be imploy'd to tiffen Linnen.
The like Gelly, but more tranparent, I have more than once made, without the help of any thing, that is enibly Acid or Urinous.

I have alo, to convince ome virtuoi, howed them omewhat to their urprie, a ubtance I had prepar'd without the help of Urine, or any volatile Alcaly, (and ometimes
almot in a trice) that would in very few minutes coagulate above twice, if not thrice its weight of highly rectify'd and inflamable vinous Spirit into a table Mas.

And to hew you, that 'tis not requiite that a Liquor be trongly, or o much as enibly Acid, to coagulate an Animal Subtance, as I lately noted, that the Spirit of Salt did the White of an egg, I hall add, that well dephlegm'd Spirit of Wine will do the ame thing as well, if not better.

div.head: PROPOSITION III.
div.p: Sometimes the Specifick Medicine may help the Patient, by precipitating the Peccant matter out of the Blood, or other Liquor (of the Body) that harbours it.

ThÃ´ Precipitation be oftentimes a conequent of the Mortification of Acids, or of Alcalies, by Corpucles
of a contrary Quality, yet I thought fit to ay omething of it apart: Becaue I have oberved that ome Acids and Alcalies may be put together without cauing Precipitation by their contrariety; and on the other ide, that divers Precipitations may be produc'd where there do's not appear any Hotility, though I know divers ingenious men, who think this Effect it elf a ufficient Argument, that the hotility of Acids and Alcalies mut be the caue of it. But that hould not be taken for granted, but prov'd by collateral Experiments, that do not uppoe the Truth of the Hypotheis it elf. But to proceed to our Exampls, I know (and elewhere mention) everal Urinous Spirits, that I could mix with Acid Mentruum without making any manifet Conflict, or Precipitation; And on the otheride, Acids and Alcalies, that will make a manifet Conflict by their mutual creation, and yet if they be mingled in a jut proportion, will have for the conequent of their
Mixture, Coalition intead of Precipitation; as may be exemplified in certain Mixtures of Spirit of Sal-Armoniac (made with Salt of Tartar, or Pot-Ahes) and Spirit of Nitre or Aqua Fortis; and alo when Spirit of Urine and Spirit of Salt, being mingled in a certain proportion, convene into Corpucles for the making of Sal-Armoniac, which the Phlegm of thoe Liquors will keep wimming. But that which makes mot for my preent purpoe, is, that there may be Precipitations, where, whatever may be uppos'd, it does not appear that there is any Tumult or Contrariety, as when Silver being diolved in Aqua Fortis, and the Mentruum diluted with 30 or 40 parts of ditill'd Water, or of Rain Water, if clean Plates of Copper be immer'd in the Solution, the Metal will be very lowly Precipitated out of it, in the form not of a Calx, coniting of Metalline, and Saline Parts incorporated together, but, at leat at the beginning in the form of pure hineing
Scales of Silver, almot like the white and glittering Scales of ome mal Fihes. There is alo a way, by which I have brought diolv'd Gold to ettle about a Body, upended in the Solution, in the form of a fine and high-colour'd Calx of pure Gold. But you may eaily ee an Intance of ilent Precipitation, if you do but rub a little either Roman or Dantzick Vitriol, upon the well whetted blade of a knife wetted with Water or Spittle, for you will have the Steel, almot in a trice, overlaid with a reddih ubtance, which by its colour and other igns appears manifetly to be Cupreous. And here I hall advertie you, that 'tis not only, as is wont to be uppos'd, out of Solutions made with Acids, that bodies may be thus Precipitated, for upon earch I have found that there are in nature Precipitants, that are capable of ilently Precipitating ome Bodies diolv'd in Urinous Mentruums, or others not Acid. I know it may be upected, and that not without colour of Reaon,
that uch Precipitations may be dangerous, by producing Heterogeneous Corpucles in the Blood, that may be too-heavy or gros to be evacuated. And I look upon this as a upicion, for whoe Reolution 'twere fit to conult Experience. But in the mean time one may repreent.

1. That, thÃ´ ome Inconvenience may happen from the Bulk of the precipitated Corpucles, yet that may be much inferiour to the danger threatned by the over-active & hotile Particles, that produc'd or fomented the dieae.

2. That, 'tis not neceary that all concretions hould conit of Corpucles o bulky, as to be too big to be thrown out of the Mas of Blood, for we ee that tony matter, which, as the Chymical Analyis of it hews, is of a very compounded nature, may be carryed to all Parts of the Body. And I remember I knew a Lady, who a while before he told me the Story, had a tone taken out of the lower
part of her Tongue. And Phyicians, that precribe great quantities of Mineral Waters impregnated with Iron, uch as I found thoe of Tunbridge to be, and with Sulphur, uch as ome of the Bath Waters are, are wont to build their expectations of Curing with them, upon a uppoition, that they are carryed into the Mas of Blood, and conequently to the innermot parts of the Body.

3. That yet 'tis poible, Precipitations may be made of matters contain'd in the Blood, by Medicines that do not get into the Mas of it. As Phyicians give Steel in Subtance ometimes crude, as well as oftentimes prepar'd, to mortify the Acidities of the Blood, though the Metalline Corpucles do not, for ought we know, pas into the Mas of it, but are wrought upon by the matter, that in its circulation is thrown out of it into the Stomach & Guts, where their operation on it is probably inferr'd from the blacknes, that Chalybeates are wont give the excrements
of the lower Belly; and if they will have it, that prepar'd Steel, for intance, calcin'd with Sulphur, gets through the Pores of the Bowels, or the extremities of the capillary Veels, into the Mas of Blood it elf, 'twill be obvious to demand, why nature hould not be able to expel Precipitate Corpucles at the ame paages, at which uch compounded Concretions, as thoe of Sulphur and Metal, can get in.

4. That ome may very peciouly pretend; that Experience has been already conulted about the expediency of imploying Precipitating Medicines. For not to urge, that the learned and judicious Sennertus eems to intimate, that in ome caes the Fibrile Matter may be urmounted by being Precipitated out of the Blood; there is a Profeor of Phyick, who, thÃ´ I cannot aent to ome of his Principles & Doctrines, has deliver'd everal coniderable things about Fermentation and Feavers: & this Profeor, by name Kergerus, very olemnly
declares Ego ab anno 1649. in hunc diem per integros 14 annos ultra mille Febricitantes ine Ven., ectione, ine Purgatione, ine Sudorieris, ine Diureticis, ine Alterantibus, ine Corrobarantibus, ine Topicis, & iquid praeterea unico fere Medicamento Praecipitante, Deo inprimis benedicente, curavi: non coniderando, an Febris it Intermittens, an Continua, an Tertiana vel Quartana (quae tamen difficilius curatur quÃ m aliae) nec expectatÃ Coctione, nec habito repectu exÃ»s, (ne p â€¢ erperis quidem exceptis) aetatis, anni, temporis, vel aliarum Circumtantiarum: & quidem paucorum dierum patio ine Recidiva vel aliquo notabili incommodo, nii ubi aeger ipe per Incontinentiam de novo Paroxymos provocarit. Kergerus de Fermentatione, ect. 3. cap. 3. Pag. mihi 250., that for fourteen years he cur'd above a thouand Febricitants without bleeding, purging, or weating Medicines, (to which he adds ome others orts) by a ingle precipitating Remedy. I endeavour'd to obtain from Germany an account of the truth of the matter of fact, but did not receive it; only I found that a Phyician of this Emperours, does, in a lately publih'd Book, declare himelf inclin'd to believe it to be true.

I hall much the more eaily be induc'd to think, that great and deireable changes may be wrought
in the fluid Parts of the Body by appropriated Precipitants, if that be true which is unanimouly taught by a multitude of Phyicians, who impute many Dieaes to the Putrefaction of the Blood and other Liquors of the Body. For, tho certain Reaons oblige me to deire you, not to ask me any Quetions about the Remedy I am going to peak of, becaue I mut not yet Anwer them; yet I am willing you hould on this occaion know Hitorically, (what probably you will think trange) that there is in rerum natura, a certain Subtance, which is o powerful an Enemy to Putrefaction, that, when a few grains or drops of it were put into a coniderable quantity of Water, that had been kept till it tunk o trongly and offenively, that, if I had not known what it was, I hould have judg'd the mell to have proceeded from Carrion. This Medicinal Liquor, I ay, (for o I may call it,) being diffus'd by agitation through this abominably tinking Water, (which did not
appear turbid to the Eye) in o very mall a proportion, Precipitated out of it a very little and light Feculency, which being eparated, the ret of the Liquor was quite freed from all tink; nor did I oberve that the Feculency it elf had any. And, which is very notable, all this was done in a very few minutes, by a Precipitant, whoe Tat was not at all either Bitter, or Acid, or Urinous, or Lixivial. All which are Circumtances, that may afford good Hints to peculative and agacious Inquirers.

div.head: PROPOSITION IV.
div.p: Sometimes the Specifick Remedy may work, by peculiarly trenthening, and cherihing the Heart, and by that means, or without it, the Part affected.

This Obervation can carce be made good, without entring into the Controvery, which for its difficulty and importance, has perplex'd divers Modern Phyicians; whether there
be any Medicines, that have a Sympathy with the Head, Heart, Liver &c and thereby deerve the name of Cephalic, Cordial, or Hepatic &c. Or, to peak omewhat more clearly, whether there be any Medicines, that in a peculiar manner do good to this or that particular internal part of the Body. In this dipute the Affirmative part has been held, but I doubt upon lender grounds of reaon, in mot of the Phyick Schools for everal Ages. But in our times, many do not only maintain the Negative, but deride the Opinion they have foraken. For ome of them object in a Triumphant Style, that tis ridiculous to fancy uch a Sympathy, betwixt a dead Medicine, and the Parts of a living body. As that the Phyician may end the Drug, as 'twere of an Errand, to find out one in the dark, among a multitude of others, and do it good offices.

But notwithtanding this, I think it very poible, that a Medicine may o far repect a particular Part, as, though not to be beneficial to that
only, yet to be friendly to that, in a peculiar manner or degree. And this I conceive it may be, upon one or more of the Accounts, that I hall briefly mention.

And Firt, when I conider that the table Parts of the Body, as the Heart, Brain, Liver, Kidneys &c. have each its particular tructure, wherein it differs from others, and probably the fluid Parts alo, as Blood, Gall, Lympha &c. have their ditinct Textures, it eems not improbable to me, that the Corpucles of a Medicine diolv'd in the Stomach, and carryed too and fro by the Liquors of the Body, may according to the determinate hape, ize, tiffnes or flexility, motion, &c. be much more fit to be detain'd by one part of the Body, as the Brain, the Heart &c. than by the ret; and o, by lodging it elf in its Pores, or aociating with its Fibres, may upply it with uch congruous Particle, as it either does want, or in cae it do not, may by their congruity be of advantage to
it, by re-etablihing or trengthening the Tone of it. And by this Corroboration, the Part may be made able to reit the Hotilities of Morbifick Matters, which Phyicians uually oberve to be wont, by the more Vigorous Parts, to be thrown upon the Weakned or Ditemper'd ones; as is manifet in perons that are much ubject to the Gout, in whom oftentimes peccant humors are very apt, upon everal occaions, to be thrown off by the nobler Parts, if they be robut, upon the frequently debilitated Joints; on which core the Gout, if it be well managed, is, not irrationally, wont to be thought conducive to long life. And on this occaion I remember, that I formerly knew a Learned Phyician, who, though a great Traveller, and, as uch, accutom'd to great varieties in point of Diet, had uch a peculiar indipoition in his Jaw, that though he could moderately drink Wines of everal orts without inconvenience, yet the drinking even of a very little Brandy, would
oon after give him the Tooth Ach, of which odd ditemper he has ometimes complain'd to me. But this upon the by: For I mut now proceed to illutrate and make probable, what I was aying of the poible fitnes of ome Medicinal Corpucles, to aociate themelves with thoe of the Part they are to befriend, by oberving what happens in Nutrition, epecially in that of ucking-children. For in thee, one ingle Aliment, namely Milk, does afford, beides various excrements, uch as the groer faeces of the Guts, and the more fluid ones of the Bladder, the Mouth, the Noe, the pores of the Skin &c. a great number of Corpucles, that are not only detain'd, but aimilated by Parts of differing Structures, as the Brain, the Heart, the Bones &c. ince otherwie thee parts could never be o plentifully nourihed by them, as dayly to increae in all their Dimenions. And tis coniderable, that ome Parts, which in Babes are Cartilaginous, do in proces of time become Boney,
which change eems not probably referable to the bare exiccation, produc'd by Native heat, increaing with the Perons Age.

Secondly, the friendly Corpucles of a Specifick Medicine, may not only confirm the good etate of a determinate Part, but, which makes mot for our preent purpoe, they may very much conduce to retore it to a ound condition, when it is ditempered, and this they may do upon two or three Accounts.
