For in the firt place, thoe friendly Particles may dipoe the Obtructing or other Morbifick matter, to be more eaily and afely expell'd. And this they may do, not barely as they impregnate the whole Mas of Blood, and o may be carried by it, as well to many other Parts, as to that we now conider; but as by their particular Texture, Motion &c. they may in a peculiar manner repect that peculiar Modification, which the Peccant matter may have acquir'd by being produc'd or harbour'd in that
determinate part: And that the ditinct Structure of an affected Part may much diverifie the condition of a Morbifick matter, I argue from this, among other things, that Phyicians are wont to teach (though I have found the Obervation rather to hold commonly than unreervedly) that in thoe that are ubject to this Stone, the Petrecent matter, when it is bred in the Kidneys is reddih or yellowih, but when in the Bladder, white, or of a light gray; and that the Stones that are generated in the firt nam'd Parts, are more friable, or at leat of a lighter Texture, than thoe that have their Original in the Bladder, ome of which are exceeding hard, epecially in comparion of large ones, that I have had out of the Bladder or Gall of luty Animals. The aptnes then that the Corpucles of the Specifick may give the Blood, or other Liquor that conveys them, to act as an appropriated Mentruum, upon the peculiarly modified Matter that obtructs, or otherwie diaffects,
the Liver, for Intance, may enable the Remedy, to be very helpful to that Part, by preparing the moleting Matter for expulion. But it may alo uccour the ame Part in another way.

For in the econd place, it may o work upon the Fibres, and table portion of the Part affected, as both to enable it, and excite it to free its elf from its Enemy. For it may give firmnes and trength to the Fibres of the part; it may alo contemperate, or correct the immoderate heat, coldnes &c. of it: It may mortify the Acid, or other incongruous Particles, that are lodg'd in the minute Intervals of the table Parts, end perhaps, even in the Pores of the Fibres: It may appeae its Convulions, Cramps, or other inordinate motions, that hinder it from daily executing its proper Functions; it may relax or widen the Pores, according to the exigency of the work to be perform'd. And having thus, by means of its friendly Corpucles, prepar'd the
matter to be expell'd, and dipoed the part to expell it, it may then alo excite the Part to do its office, by irritating the Fibres, or motive Organs, or timulating them to disburthen the Part of the Matter that offends it, as a very mall Doe of Cantharides is known by this way of irritation, to be capable of making the Bladder forcibly, though not afely, dicharge it elf of Urine, and with that oftentimes expel the Sand and Gravel, or leer Stones, and the Excrementitious Slime that moleted it before.

And this Intance may be of ue to us, in anwering that which we formerly noted to be o confidently urged by the Rejecters of Specifick Medicines. For here we have a Medicine, though a dangerous one, whoe Corpucles have uch a peculiar reference to the Bladder, and Urinary Organs, that though being gotten into the Mas of Blood, they are carried by it indicriminately to other parts of the Body, as well as to thee; yet
oftentimes, without manifetly diaffecting the ret, they exceedingly irritate the Bladder, and determine it to the excretion of what it contains. And whereas it may be objected, that the firt of the three ways, by which we noted, that a particular Part may be uccour'd by a Specifick, eems contrary to the econd; the former tending to corroborate the Part, and the later to relax and irritate it: I anwer two things, one, that ince the Part may be ometimes in a Natural, and ometimes in a Preternatural tate, in the former, a Medicine may deerve the name of Friendly or Appropriated, becaue it keeps it ound, which is mot properly done by trengthening it; and in the later it may merit the Title of a Specifick, becaue it helps to retore it to a tate of oundnes: And the other, that though to effect this Recovery, 'tis often very expedient, if not neceary, that the Medicine procure an Evacuation of ome matter that offends it; yet that Evacuation
itelf is often much promoted and facilitated, by tengthening the Part o, as to enable it to disburthen it elf. And the ame Medicine may contain, and communicate to the Blood, Corpucles of uch differing hapes, izes, motions &c. as may at leat ucceively relieve the Part by both thee ways; as Phyicians oberve that Rhubarb does, not only by its finer and Laxative Parts, purge the Liver of Choler, but by its more earthy Atringent Corpucles trengthen the Tone of that Part: [What farther belongs to the Illutration of this matter will be met with in due place.] On this occaion, 'twill not be impertinent to add, that in ome caes, this very Corroboration of a Ditempered Part, may retore it to oundnes; there being ome Dieaes of uch a nature, that they are, if I may o peak, almot always in Fieri, that is, they could not continue to ubit in the affected Part, unles through its debility, and the conequences of it, it were ubject to admit from
time to time freh recruits of peccant matter, to foment the Malady: And in uch Ditempers, if the Structure and Tone of the Part be re-etablihed by the operation of the Specifick Medicine, its acquir'd vigour will enable it to reit the Ingres of new upplies of peccant Matter, and to turn them off into the Mas of Blood, to be thence dicharg'd by the Common Shores of the Body; whilt in the mean time Nature will be able by degrees to ubdue, diipate, or otherwie dipoe of, that comparatively little Portion of peccant Matter, that was lodg'd in the Dieas'd Part.

We have not in this Paper given any Example of the peculiar repect of a Specifick Medicine to a determinate diaffected Part, that one would think o incredible, as that a heavy tony ubtance, being in no great quantity taken in at die Mouth, hould manifetly contribute to the Cure of a broken Bone in one of the Limbs, as the Leg or the Hands. And yet, not to urge the Tetimony of
Chymical Writers, I remember a German Phyician, that was Famous for notable Cures, related Wonders to me of the efficacy of that Stone growing in his Country, which from its effect they call Oteocolla, epecially if it be improv'd by a Skilful Preparation, which he communicated to me, but I had not opportunity to make Tryal of it. But without Preparation, the judicious and long experienc'd Chirurgeon Fabricius Hildanus much commends upon his own Obervation a ingle Dram of it finely Powder'd, for the breeding of a Callus to oder together the Parts of a broken Bone: Inomuch that he gives a caution to ue it but paringly in young and vigorous Patients, let it breed too great a Callus, of which he gives a notable Intance. And the like caution was inculcated to me from Experience, by the lately mention'd German Doctor, becaue otherwie (he aid) his Preparation would in uch Perons make the Medicine generate a Callus too oon and too great.

div.head: PROPOSITION V.
div.p: Sometimes a Specifick Medicine may do its work, by producing in the Mas of Blood, uch a dipoition, as may enable Nature, by correcting, expelling or other fit waies, to urmount the morbifick Matter, or other Caue of the Dieae.

He that hall heedfully oberve the practie of divers Learned and uccesful modern Phyitians, may dicern that many, if not mot, of their Precriptions are founded upon a uppoition, that a great Part of the Dieaes incident to Mans Body, and the recovery from them, depends mainly upon the vitiated Contitution of the Blood, and the retoring it to a ound Condition.
This advantageous change of the Blood may be effected by a Specifick, everal waies, (ometimes eparately, and ometimes jointly,) and particularly by thoe that follow.
1. That which I hall firt name, is, by furnihing the Blood with ome ort of active Corpucles, that it needs to ferment it, or excite an ueful Commotion or Agitation in it.

I will not here examine, whether the Mas of Blood, contain'd within the Veels of a living man, is capable of a Fermentation properly and trictly o call'd; and therefore I employ'd alo the word Commotion, which will be eaily admitted, if the other be diliked. But in regard Fermentation is a Term that hath generally obtain'd, I hall not cruple to make ue of it, after what I have intimated about it.

But becaue many modern Phyitians, epecially ince the Learned Dr. Willis's Notions came to be in requet, have looked upon Feavers and Agues to conit in, or be produc'd by vitious Fermentations of the Blood; I thought fit to add to the Fermentation I am about to peak of, the ditinguihing Epithets of ueful.

This premis'd, it eems not improbable to me, that, as there is oftentimes a vitious Fermentation of the Blood, o there may be ometimes a want of Fermentation, or a certain Sluggihnes, upon whoe account, either the brisk intetine Agitation, that it ought to have as a warm Fluid of uch a Nature as 'tis wont to be in ound Perons, or a due quicknes of Circulation through the Heart is wanting: To which Sluggih State of the Blood, if it be obtinate and lating everal Ditempers are wont to be conequent. Now, although there be divers Medicines, uch as Spices, Brandy, and other Spirituous Liquors ditill'd from fermented vegetables, that are uually, and oftentimes uccesfully enough, employ'd to correct this dull Indipoition of the Blood; Yet in regard they are wont to be very hot, being uually pitch'd upon by thoe that precribe them becaue they are o; there are everal contitutions of
Patients, and divers other Circumtances, wherein they are not afe, but may do more harm by their immoderate Heat, than good by their Spirituoity, Beides, that the Sluggihnes of the Blood may ometimes proceed from Caues, that this ort of hot Medicines will not correct. I remember, that having for Tryals ake moderately dry'd a parcel of Human Blood, a Vinous Spirit Total inflammable would not, at leat in many hours that my Experiment lated, make a Solution of it, or draw a red Tincture from it, though it were well pulveris'd: Whereas a well rectified rinous Spirit grew red upon it in les than the tenth, or perhaps the twentieth, part of that Time.

Now a Specifick Medicine may abound in Corpucles of uch a Nature, that without dangerouly, or incommodiouly heating the Blood, they may diable thoe Corpucles, they meet with in the Blood, that make that Liquor vicous, or roapy, or dipirited;
and alo by enlivening the Mas of Blood, if I may o peak, or puting it into a more brisk and kindly Agitation, may make it fit to throw off thoe Heterogeneous Parts, or recrements, that were blended with it before, and to permeate, as freely as it ought, the Vicera, whoe Capillary Veels and Pores would formerly carce, and but very paringingly, admit it.

That a Specifick may perform this, you will perhaps the more eaily allow, if you conider, that the generality of Phyitians teach, that there are everal Cordials, which they tyle ome of them Temperate, and divers of them Cold, (as in effect 'tis not uually oberv'd, that they coniderably, if at all enibly, heat the Body;) as Pearls, and ome of them, being gratefully Acid, hould rather cool it, as Wood-orrel (Alleluja) and Goats-Rue (Galega.) And 'tis very poible, that the Corpucles, that make the Blood thick, and Sluggih, may not be of a Cold Nature, but of
a Hot, and therefore may have their Effects rather befriended than detroy'd by divers Hot Remedies: As, if the white of an Egg be by beating reduc'd to Water, (which is not neceary to the Experiment, but hews it better) if you put to it a certain Proportion of well dephlegm'd Spirit of Wine, intead of detroying the vicoity of the Liquor, it will curdle a good part of it, and thereby produce a Body far more remote from Thinnes and Fluidity.

And I remember, I once for Tryal ake made a vegetable Liquor, which, from omewhat Sluggih that it was before, did preently by the Addition of a little Spirit of Wine, grow urpriingly vicous, and roapy.

2. Another way, by which a Specifick may befriend the Mas of Blood, is, by imparting to it a dilatation or tenuity that it wants. This Second way is of much affinity to the Firt, but yet is not the ame: Becaue in that, the thing mainly conidered was, the Fermentation or Agitation
of the Blood; Whereas this mainly repects the Conitence of it, which is a thing of no mean importance to health. For if the Blood be too thick, as oftentimes it is, it cannot pas o freely and readily, as it ought, through the Capillary Veels, which thereby come to be by little and little obtructed, and the Circulation inconveniently retarded; Whence 'tis eay to foreee, that divers michiefs mut in time arie. And on the other ide, if the Blood be too thin, epecially if it be over much agitated too, tis apt to make its way out of the Veels, and produce Hemorrhagies, in cae it flow out of the Body, or other bad Effects that uually attend the Extravaation of the Blood. Which Liquor, when it is out of its proper Veels, in o warm a place as a Living Human Body, is very Subject to Putrefaction, and thereby apt to produce Impothumes and everal michievous Symptoms.

Now a Specifick Medicine may remedy this faulty Conitence of the
Blood, by furnihing it with Corpucles, fitted by their figure, bulk, motion, &c. to diable thoe peccant ones that make the Blood gros, or ele to cut, or divide the Parts of the Blood it elf, and o dipoe them to be more fluid: Or ele they may produce in it uch Pores, as may, as it were invite the ubtil Aetherial matter, that abounds in the Atmophaere, to ininuate it elf into the Mas of Blood, and rarifie it. And on the other ide, when the Blood is too thin, as not only ome Dieaes, but ome Medicines, epecially Aloes, are wont to make it; A Specifick Remedy may reduce it to a good Conitence, either, by furnihing it with Corpucles, apt to Combine themelves with the active ones, that did too much Attenuate the Blood; Or, by helping Nature to expel thoe over-buy Particles, by inenible Tranpiration, or ome other unditurbing way.

3: There is yet another way, by which a Specifick Remedy may conduce
to rectifie the State of the Blood And that is, by o working on the Heart, as to make it advantageouly regulate the Tranmiion of that Liquor through it.

That a Specifick Medicine may peculiarly befriend this or that particular Part, and conequently the Heart, is granted by the Generality of Phyitians, who are wont to reckon up many Cordials, (of which yet I fear, but few deerve that name.) But, ince 'tis elewhere in this Paper hewn, that ome Medicines may particularly repect a determinate Part of the Body, and conequently the Heart; One may be allowed to uppoe, that the Corpucles of a Specifick may either diolve ome Particles they meet with in the Heart, by which that Noble Vicus is by Irritation, or otherwie diturb'd in the Regularity of its Dilatations, and Contractions; Or, o Corroborate the Fibres, or Motive Organs of it, as to dipoe it to moderate the Circulation of the Blood that paes
through it, in the mot advantageous way. And that the Dipoition of the Heart, even when men have no ene of it in the Part it elf, may be of moment as to health and icknes, will appear credible, if we reflect on two thing. One, that a living Human Body is not a meer Aggregate of Fleh, Bones, &c. But an exquiitely contriv'd, and very enible Engine; Whoe Parts are eaily et a work by proper, though very Minute, Agents; And may, by their Action upon one another, perform far greater things, than could be expected from the bare Energy of the Agents, that firt put them into Motion. The Second, (which uppoes the firt,) that the Dipoition of the Heart, being, though perhaps inenibly, chang'd, it may produce a notable Alteration in the Motions of the Blood, and its paage through the Heart, in point of quantity, celerity, or both.

How much this change in the Circulation may in many Caes conduce
to icknes or recovery may partly appear by the Effects of vehement or durable paions of the mind. As 'tis oberv'd, that in a deep orrow, which does in a manner traiten the Paages of the Heart, the Blood being too paringly dipens'd, the enlivening Spirits are not generated plentifully enough; And (beides other bad Effects of this State of the Heart) the Blood is o dipirited, as (in thee Parts of Europe) to dipoe the Body to the Scurvy, which does either produce or irritate divers other Maladies. We ee alo, that the Paion of hame does oftentimes uddenly alter the Motion of the Blood, and make it well the little Veels that lye under the Cuticula of the Face, and ometimes other Parts; as is very manifet in young Maids, and other Perons of a Delicate Complexion, the white Part of whoe Faces in bluhing turns Red. The like Effect I have een produc'd by a great and udden Joy. And though Grief, which is the oppoite Paion
to it, has been uually taken notice of, as a thing that deads the Appetite to meat; Yet o much does depend upon a well moderated Transmiion of the Blood, that it has been oberv'd in divers Perons, and I have known an eminent Intance of it, that great Joy has very much leen'd Hunger: Of which Effect Mr. Des Cartes ingeniouly attempts to derive the caue, from the vary'd Dilatation and Motions of the Heart. And it eems not abur'd to conceive, that uch like Motions may be caus'd by the Corpucles of a Specifick Medicine; Which by affecting the Fibres of the Heart, after the like manner that Joy is wont to do, may produce in it uch friendly Dilatations and Contractions, as are wont to flow from the agreeable Paions. In favour of which conjecture, I hall take notice that a Lady of my acquaintance has complain'd to me, that the mell of perfum'd Gloves is wont to make the Blood fly to her Face, and continue there for a great
while, giving it uch a colour as if hame, or joy had cover'd it with bluhes. And the like he ays he has oberv'd in others of her Sex. But having in another Tract poken of the power of the Paions of the mind, to alter the tate of the Body, by producing changes in the Blood, that is tranmitted through the Heart; what has been aid may now uffice to make it credible, that a Specifick Remedy, by peculiarly befriending the Heart, may contribute much to introduce, or re-etablih a healthy Crais in the Blood. And this being thus rectified, and invigorated it elf, may both befriend the Body in general, and conduce to the removal of ome particular Dieaes, by trengthening, and perhaps too exciting, the particular part, in which the peccant matter reides, to ubdue or expel that which it already harbours, and reit any acceion of more. And the Blood, being it elf well contituted, as well as the table Parts corroborated, the
Specifick Medicine that produces thee good effects, may be aid to cure, tho' perhaps but lowly, divers particular Dieaes; uch as thoe elewhere mention'd in this Paper, which to continue, mut be frequently upplyed with vitious matter by the Circulating Blood.

div.head: EXPERIMENT VI.
div.p: Sometimes a Specifick Remedy may unite its Particles with thoe of the Peccant matter, and with them contitute a Neutrum quid, that may be eaily procrib'd, or not neceary to be expell'd.

This I take to be one of the mot proper and genuine ways of doing good, that belongs to a Specifick Medicine, as uch, becaue in this operation an effect is produc'd, either without the aitance, or beyond the meer power, of the manifet qualities (as Phyicians call them) of the remedy;
and the cure or relief the Patient finds, is uually attain'd without violence, and without tormenting or much diordering him.

This way of working of a Specifick Medicine is of near affinity with one or two of thoe formerly dicours'd of; but yet thee ways differ in ome things, as may be gather'd by the equel of Â§ this dicoure Â§ ometimes when a certain kind of Acid has impregnated the Blood, or lodg'd it elf in ome table part, as the Liver, Spleen, Kidneys, &c. The Corpucles of a Specifick may, without any enible luctation or conflict, which uually happens when Acids are mortify'd by Sapid Alkalies, be o qualifi'd, as both to make Coalitions with the mall Parts of the Peccant Acid, and with them to contitute little Concretions, which differing from the minute Parts of the Acid, either in Bulk, Figure, Solidity, Stifnes, Motion, or in two or more of thee; may be quite of another nature, and of a much innocenter,
than the Acid was before 'twas o corrected. Of this we may be furnihed with a notable Illutration, by what I have elewhere taken notice of about Aqua Fortis it elf; for as corroive a Mentruum as that is, yet by digeting it, and perhaps, ditilling it too, with an equal, or rather double weight of Ardent Spirit, I found the highly Acid Liquor would be o chang'd, as not to retain any enible corroivenes; and exchange its piercing Stink and great Acidity, for a not only inoffenive, but pleaant Scent, and a grateful and poitively weetih Tat. Which brings into my mind the practice of a Preident of the Famous London Colledge, who (as himelf told me) was wont to relieve a Patient of very great Quality in Nephritick Torments, by giving her a good Doe of an inflammable Spirit. (But this upon the by.) I have elewhere given an account of the effects of Spirit of Wine, upon everal other Acid Mentruums, wherewith I mingl'd and digeted it; by
which it may appear, that it does not work upon them uniformly, as they are all of them Acids; but differingly enough, according to the Nature and Proportion of the Acid Corpucles, with which the vinous Spirits are brought to be aociated.

And, to hew that this change and contemperation of the Mentruum by the Spirit of Wine, is produc'd rather by a peculiar fitnes of the convening Corpucles of both, than by the contrariety or hotility, that the vinous Spirit, which ome Moderns will have to be an Alcaly, has to the Aqua Fortis as an Acid; I hall add, that pure Spirit of Wine being mixt in a due proportion with Highly rectifi'd Spirit of Urine; which is reckon'd by Chymits among volatile Alcalies, and of which a drop or two is o fiery upon the tongue; as to be ready to burn it, or to bliter it; this Vinous Spirit I ay, will very much take off the cautick penetrancy of the urinous one, and compoe with it a Salt much
more moderate than the Spirit was, and which being ublim'd, or (which is better but harder to be done,N. B.) reduc'd into a Liquor, affords a mixture of no little ue in fome Fevers and other Dieaes as a Medicine; and with a mall, if skilful alteration, is of great ue in divers Chymical Experiments as a Mentruum.

A few grains of Glas of Antimony made without addition, being taken inwardly, will vehemently both vomit and purge. But tho' Wine, notwithtanding its copious Spirits, will, if it be well impregnated with the Corpucles of this Glas, work upwards and downwards violently enough; yet of Spirit of Vinegar, that is, of degenerated Wine, be for a competent time digeted upon this Glas finely powder'd, and, when the Liquor is ufficiently impregnated with the Particles of the Glas, be abtracted from it, there will emerge from the Antimonial and Acetous Corpucles, a multitude of minute Concretions, of which many grains may
be given without ordinarily provoking either Vomits or Stools: Which correction may hint, that 'tis not neceary that all Mortifications uefully made by Medicines, hould be of Acids, ince here we ee, that Acids themelves prove Correctors. And perhaps it may be by ome uch kind of Combinations, that ome Poions (for I do not think they all work one way, or peculiarly aault the heart) may be ubdued. And I have ometimes upected, that it may as probably be upon this account, as upon any that has been offer'd, that a man tung with a Scorpion may be cur'd, by cruhing the Animal that tung him upon the hurt, as is precrib'd by many Phyicians, and as an acquaintance of mine told me, he try'd upon himelf (as another Virtuoo did on a Souldier) with good ucces: And when I conider what a multitude and variety of figures may fit the Corpucles that are endowed with them, to make Coalitions very different from both
the component parts; I can carce think it very improbable, that in a Patients Body there may be made, between the Corpucles of the Peccant matter, and thoe of a Medicine, uch ueful combinations as may produce reulting Concretions, innocent, if not alo beneficial.

If I had leizure, and thought it fit, I could eaily add a great number of intances, about uch changes of Colours, Odours, Tats, and other qualities, as are produc'd by the coallecence of the mall parts of differing Bodies, and dicoure of the natural conequent of uch Coalitions: but having done that ufficiently in other Papers, it will be here more proper to intimate to you, that when a particle of peccant matter comes to be aociated with one of a Specifick Medicine, that combination may alter it for the better, not only by changing its bignes and figure, but alo by encreaing, or leening its tifnes, and its olidity, and giving a new modification to its motion; as
a little attention to the natural conequences of the Coalitions of Bodies, may eaily induce you to grant.

And I hall add (as it were ex abundanti) that the mall Concretions, made by the union of ome Morbifick with ome Medicinal Corpucles, may not only become innocent, but ometimes alo beneficial, which may be illutrated by what happens by a further preparation, to common ublimate; for though this be a ubtance o highly corroive and michievous, that a few grains of it may uffice to kill a man; yet by making a Coalecence of it with les than its weight of Quickilver, which is a Body inipid as well as modorous, the Corroive ublimate will be o alter'd and tam'd, as to be turn'd into what Chymits call, becaue 'tis freed from harpnes, Mercurius Dulcis; which if it be skilfully prepar'd and given, though in the quantity of many grains, is not only for the mot part an innocent thing, but a very good Medicine, and that perhaps in more
caes than Phyicians generally know it to be good in.

The newly mention'd account may hint to us a probable Argument, to how, that, notwithtanding all the digetions and changes that a Specifick Medicine may receive in its way, it may prove a alutary one, when it arrives at the Part it hould relieve. For, tho' the Corpucles of the Medicine hould in their way to the Part affected be coniderably chang'd, yet 'tis poible that thee alter'd Corpucles may, by that very alteration, be made Medicinal; ince they may be qualifi'd, (even by thoe changes) when they arrive at the Part affected, to combine themelves trictly with ome Corpucles, whether Morbifick or others, that they find already there; and may with them compoe new Concretions that may acquire a new Nature very friendly to the Patient. Something Analogical to this we may oberve in Aparagus, which being eaten, afford tore of Particles, that mixing with
thoe they meet with in the Kidneys or the Bladder, produce a new Odour, very differing, both from that of meer Urine, and from that of the Plant it elf. And o if good Turpentine be taken at the Mouth, 'tis known that arriving at the Kidneys and Bladder, it will mingle its minute Parts with thoe it meets with there; whence will emerge Corpucles, that will impregnate the Urine with a very differing Odour, from that which belongs to either of the Liquors, ince it oftentimes has a fragrancy omewhat like the mell of Violets.

Before I conclude this Paper, 'tis like it will be thought fit that I hould take notice of a difficulty, that I know maybe objected, if not againt the pat dicoure, yet againt the ufficiency of it to anwer the deign I propoe to my elf in writing it. For it may be aid, that, whereas my Arguments and Explications uppoe all along, that the Specifick Remedies are taken in at the Mouth; 'tis known
that divers of the Aerters of Specificks reckon among them, ome that are not by wallowing taken into the Body, but only outwardly apply'd, or perhaps do but barely touch it; as may be oberv'd in Amulets, Rings, &c. On occaion of this coniderable difficulty, I have, if I miremember not, repreented divers things in another Tract. But however it may be fit in this place, briefly to ay omewhat, by way of Anwerto it. We may then take notice, that the confidence with which many Phyicians reject, and ome of them deride, External Specificks, if I may o call them, eems to be built upon thee two things: The One, that the Medicine cannot in part, as 'tis certain it do's not in the Mas, get into the Body; and the other, that, in cae a Specifick hould have ome part of it ubtil enough to gain admittance, that Part mut be too mall and inconiderable, to be able to produce in the Body any uch notable change, as is neceary to the expulion of Peccant Humours,
and the conquering of a Dieae.

As to the former of thee Grounds, I largely enough how in another Paper,The Paper here mean't is the Eay of the Poroity of bodys. that a Mans Skin, tho' it eems an entire continued Body, is really perforated with a great multitude, and perhaps a not inconiderable variety, of little Cutlets and Inlets, which we call Pores; many of which are viible, even in the Skins of dead Animals, by good Microcopes; and others are manifetly inferr'd, from the numerous little drops that cover all the Skin, at the firt Eruption of Sweat. And that thee little Perforations may be Inlets to the finer Particles of Externally apply'd Medicines, may appear probable by everal Phaenomena, uch as thee. That Water will oak through the Pores of a fine Bladder, and diolve Salt of Tartar, or even white Sugar, contain'd in it: That I have prepar'd a certain Liquor, whoe Fumes, tho' not agitated by Heat, would quickly penetrate
divers Membrans of dead Animals, and manifetly work on Metalline Bodies wrapt up in them: That 'tis a known thing, that Quickilver outwardly apply'd in Ointments, Girdles, &c. will get in at the Pores of the Skin, and invade the Internal Parts of the Body, and tay there longer, and perhaps too operate more, than the Phyician deired. And when once the Effluvia of thee Externally apply'd Remedies have gain'd admittance at the Pores of the Skin, 'tis not very difficult to conceive, how they may proceed further. For underneath the Cuticula or Scarf Skin, and cloe to it, there are o great a multitude of Capillary Veels, that you can carce thrut a mall Pin into any Part, but that the point of it will meet and tear ome of thee little Veels; as will appear by a mall drop of Blood, that will be made to iue out at the new made hole, as mall as it is. To which intance, if it were neceary, I could add divers others of the multitude and
preading of the Capillary Veels, that lie cloe beneath the Skin, and for the mot part carry Blood, tho' ome of them may contain other Juices, and dicharge their recrements by Sweat, or inenible Tranpiration, at the Cutaneous Outlets. Now thee Capillary Veels, as mall as they are, having their Cavities immediately continu'd with thoe of les lender ones, and by their intervention with thoe of the greater, which are branches of the greatet of all; the Corpucles of the Medicine, once got into the Capillary Veels, may have an eay paage, by means of the Liquors they contain, into thee greater branches of the principal Veins, and o, by vertue of the Circulation, come to be quickly mingled with the Mas of Blood, and by it may be eaily convey'd to all the Parts of the Body: As it has been divers times oberv'd, See this at large proved by the Learned Diemerbro â€¢â€¢ k de Pete, lib. 2. cap. 11. in Annotat. that Arenical Amulets worn upon the Breat, did,
tho' they carce touch'd the Skin, produce threatning Ditempers in the Heart, and everal michievous Symptoms in other Parts of the Body. And I find it recorded in good Authors, that Cantharides, even when but held in the Hand, nay ometimes, tho' but carried in ones Pocket, tranmitted their hurtful Effluvia as far as the Bladder, and excited great Pain and other bad Symptoms there.

As for the econd Ground on which Specifick Remedies are rejected, that, tho' they could get entrance into the Body, yet it would be but by their Effluvia; and thee are no way likely to prove efficacious enough, to have any coniderable effect upon an Internal Dieae: To remove this difficulty, I hall briefly oberve;

1. That the number of the Corpucles, that may pas from the outward Medicine into the Body, may be far greater, and therefore make them more coniderable, than mot men are apt to think. This may be
rendred probable, by the great multitudes of Odorous, and conequently Senible, Expirations, that are continually emitted for a very long time together, by Ambergreece, Musk, Civet, and much more by skilfully made Compoitions of them. And that alo ubtil Effluvia, even without the aitance of Heat, may quickly penetrate Membrans o plentifully, as to act on table Bodies contain'd in them, I have intimated a little above, and have experimentally made appear to divers curious men.

2. That the Corpucles of a Medicine may retain their Nature, and not looe their power of operating, notwithtanding their being, as it were, train'd through the Skin; as may be argued from the Mercury, that we not long ince mention'd to have been found in the form of Quick-ilver, in the Bodies of ome men, that had been too frequently anonited with Mercury, mix'd up with unctuous things into an Ointment: By which
the Patient may be as long and violently Salivated, as if he had wallow'd a Bolus or Pills with Mercury.

And o I have divers times oberv'd, as I doubt not but others have oftner done, that a little Opium, mix'd up with other Ingredients for Plaiters, did by outward application take off the Acute Pains of inward Parts, tho' moderately remote from the Plaiter.

3. And that the Corpucles of a Specifick may on divers occaions act more powerfully, by getting in at the Pores of the Skin, than if the Remedy that afforded them had been taken in at the Mouth: Becaue if it had, the Particles might be divided, or perhaps on other accounts, (as by dilution, compoition with thoe of the Chyle, &c.) much alter'd, by the Ferment or the Mentruum of the Stomach, by their Filtration through the Guts, and their long and winding paage through them and the Lymphiducts, before they arrive at the Heart, to be mingled with the Blood;
whereas the Corpucles of the External Specifick, preently after they are pat the Skin, get into the Capillary Veels of the Blood that lie under it, and by their means are peedily mix'd with the Circulating Mas of that Liquor, and o ecape the formerly mention'd alterations, that other Medicines are ubject to before they are admitted into the Mas of Blood. By which it may appear, that thoe Phyicians are much mitaken, that think a Topical Medicine can at bet relieve but the Part 'tis apply'd to, becaue its Corpucles cannot be uppos'd to reach beyond that Part of the Body, that lies very near the Medicine they iue from. But, tho' this reaoning might be excuable enough, if not allowable, before the Circulation of the Blood was dicover'd, yet, now 'tis known how great an intercoure that Liquor maintains between ditant Parts of the Body, the Argument is not eaonable.

And on this occaion, I hall add an advertiement, that I remember
not I have met with in Authors; which is, that Body's outwardly apply'd may prove Specificks for ome Dieaes or Ditempers, that one would not think them very good for, by the bare knowledge of their effects when taken in at the mouth. Thus Camphire wallow'd, is, in the doe of a very few grains, a great heater of the Blood, and is in ome Country's, perhaps not altogether without reaon, extoll'd by Phyicians in ome kinds of ill condition'd Fevers: but outwardly it is apply'd to take off thoe Rednees of the Face, that are thought to proceed from Heat of Blood; and 'tis us'd in Ointments againt Burns. So Spirit of Wine, that is o hot when drunk, is a very good remedy to take out the fire, as they peak, in Burns, epecially if the Part be early moitend with it. Bread, that is counted o moderate and well temper'd and Aliment, when eaten, if it be chew'd and outwardly apply'd, hath coniderable vertues in everal external affections. And I know an
ancient and experienc'd Phyician, that ues to purge. Children, that will not eaily be brought to wallow Medicines, by applying omething to their Navels, that do's not offend them by Colour, Smell, or Griping: And this himelf more than once confes'd to me, is but an ordinary Aliment, that mot men, and I among others, have frequently taken unprepar'd, which he freely nam'd to me, but which I have not yet had opportunity to make Tryal of.

That what we have been aying about the poible efficacy of external Specificks, may appear the les improbable, 'twill be fit to take notice of oms obervations, that comport very well with our Doctrine. And though the Intances to be brought will not be all of them of remedies that deerve the name of Specificks; yet, beides that ome of them may perhaps have a Title to it, they will all conduce to how, that Simples or Druggs externally apply'd, may have coniderable operations againt Internal Ditempers of the Body.

'Twere eay for me to mention a great many external Specificks out of Phyicians Books. But I purpoely forbear it, becaue to peak freely, I upect that mot of thoe Remedies, though greatly extoll'd, have been but little examin'd, by the deliverers of them. And it may uffice for my preent purpoe to alledge a few Intances that have been recommended to me, either by my own experience, or that of ome Friends. Only there is one obervation that is o olemnly and exprely deliver'd by Galen, upon his own knowledge, & o well back'd, by other eminent Phyicians, that I hall let it lead the way. This memorable tory, that is related by Galen, is of a Piony Root, which having been worn as ah Apenum about a Boy, that had been Epileptick for divers months, kept him from his Dieae as long as he wore it about him; but when by an accident he ceas'd to do o, the Dieae invaded him again, and yet by applying the Remedy again, he was the econd
time freed from it, which Galen oberving, did for curioity make the Root be laid aide, but finding the Fits to return, he imploy'd it again with the former ucces.

I liv'd in the ame houe with a learned and Judicious Peron, that was ubject to be Paralytick, who being frequently tortur'd by violent Cramps, was ordinarily and peedily reliev'd by wearing or handling the Tooth of a true Hippopotamus or River-Hore. And he affirm'd to me, that upon leaving off, the ue of it, for any coniderable time, either out of curioity, or to accommodate ome Friend, the Fits would return with violence upon him. I remember alo, that having my elf been for ome years frequently ubject to Cramps, and complaining of it to a Phyician that had been a Traveller into cold Country's, he told me, that he had brought home with him ome Rings made of the true Elks hoof, from a place where thee Animals are uually imploy'd, and that with thee he had
cur'd many of the Cramp, and therewithal preented me one to make tryal of, which I the more willingly accepted, becaue he confes'd to me, that divers Rings that were old for uch as his, and look'd like them, were either counterfeit or of no efficacy. And tho' I did not find that if the Cramp eiz'd me in the calf of the Leg, the Ring would much relieve me, yet when the Fits were but moderate, and in other Parts, epecially the hands, I found my elf ea'd, o often, and o oon, that I was at firt urpriz'd at it, and us'd to have the remedy laid every night by my Bed-ide, to have it ready when occaion hould require. And that which I thought ome what trange, was, that everal times, when the Cramp eiz'd my Foot or my Toes, the Pain was quickly remov'd, tho' I apply'd the Ring but to my Finger: which made me much regret the los of it.

An eminent Phyician peaking to me one day of a Patient of his, that was ubject to a nocturnal Incontinentia
Urinae, that was very inconvenient as well as hameful; I told him of an Empyrical Remedy, which is mention'd in another Paper, whoe ucces I neither would warrant, nor did altogether dipair of, and which at leat eem'd afe, tho' it hould not prove effectual. This was only a imple ubtance, (belonging to the Animal Kingdom) that was to be worn in a ine Saranet Bag between the Shift and the Skin, for which a good while after the Phyician gave me great thanks, telling me, that he was urpriz'd at the effect of it, and that he oberv'd that when the Patient had worn it o long, that probably the vertue began to decay, that is in my ene, that the Effluvia were almot pent, the Patient found need to take a freh Remedy, to continue the benefit he had found by the former.

I do not affirm or expect, that the three fornam'd Appena, nor the other Remedy's I am about to mention, will always ucceed. And I
think, one may aign ome not improbable reaons of the want of uniformity in their effects. But for my preent argument, it uffices that they do ometimes ucceed, ince that is enough to how it poible, that outward Medicines may operate upon inward Ditempers.

Having one day given a viit to one of the skilfullet and candidet Phyicians of the Famous Colledge of London, I oberv'd in his Chamber, a fine new fahion'd Clock; and having taken notice of it to him, as a thing I had not een there before; he deir'd me not to think, he was rich and vain enough to purchae, o dear a rarity; but that it belong'd to a Courtier whom he nam'd to me, of whoe Daughter he told me this tory. This young Lady had a great Tumor in her Neck or Throat, which being apprehended to be of a Scrophulous Nature, made her Father fear it would oblige him to increae her Portion more than his Etate could conveniently bear. Wherefore at length
he addres'd himelf to my Relator, who judging the cae to be difficult, and being unwilling to torment the Lady with a long coure of Phyick, told the Courteour, that if he could animate her to uffer a Remedy he would propoe, and would ait him to procure it, he hop'd to remove this Tumour without weakning her, or putting her to pain. Soon after, all Parties being agreed, and the deired conveniency procur'd, the Patient was brought into a Room, where there was yet in Bed the Body of a man that had dy'd of a lingring Dieae. This mans Hand the Doctor took, and laid it upon his Patients Tumour, keeping it there till he either complain'd or confes'd that he felt the coldnes of it penetrate to the innermot Parts of her Tumour. This application was afterwards repeated more than once, whilt the Body continued without melling: And by this coure the Tumour was dipell'd, and the Patient o reliev'd, that her Father, by way of gratitude,
knowing how much the Phyician was a lover of curioities, made him a preent of that Clock.

The Learned Doctor acrib'd this odd Remedy to Helmont, who is indeed to be thank'd for having mention'd and recommended a Medicine, that was unlikely to be good, beides that it was not in ue. But the knowledge of it eems to me to have been for the main very much ancienter than our Age: ince there is mention made of one very like it by o Ancient an Author as Pliny; tho' ince his time till Helmonts it hath been generally forgotten or disbeliev'd, ave that one Phyician (Francicus Ulmus) who, tho' no ill Oberver, has not had the Fortune to be Famous, takes notice of a cae very like that of our Courtiers Daughter, affirming, that by that one Remedy, after others had been fruitlely imploy'd, he knew a Noble Virgin to have been perfectly cur'd.

I was one Summer, to my great urprize obnoxious to frequent Bleedings
at the Noe; for which I ometimes us'd one Remedy, and ometimes another, for the mot part with good, but not till with quick ucces. But falling once unexpectedly into a Fit, whoe violence omewhat alarm'd me, I reolv'd to try an unuual Remedy: And having eaily obtain'd of my Siter, in whoe houe this Accident happen'd, ome true Mos of a dead Mans Scull, which had been ent her, by a great Peron, for a preent out of Ireland, in which Country, I found it les rare and more eteem'd than elewhere: I was going to imploy it after the uual manner, which is to put it up into the Patients Notrils, but before I did it, I had the curioity to try, notwithtanding the brisknes of my Haemorrhagy, whether the Medicine would produce its effect by being only held in my Hand, and therefore covering a piece of the Mos with my Fit, that the warmth might a little actuate the Medicine, I found, to the wonder of the by-tanders,
that the Blood peedily topp'd, nor thanks be to God have I been troubled with a Haemorrhagy for ome years from that very time. But this is far les trange than what was affirm'd to have happen'd to one of the Eminentet Members of the Royal Society. This Learned Gentleman, who was of a very Sanguine Complexion, found himelf much affected by the ue of the Mos of a human Scull, [pieces of which I have een ticking to the Roots of the Vegetable, when it was genuine] which had o trange an operation upon him, that ometimes when he was let Blood, if for curioities ake he held a quantity of this Mos in his Hand, the Efflux of the Blood would ceae, till he laid it by again; which was not only olemnly averr'd to me by himelf, but confirm'd to me by his Ingenious Phyician, with both whom I had a particular Acquaintance; which otherwie I hould have thought carce credible, unles imagination, a faculty very trong in that Gentleman,
contributed to the trange effect of the Remedy.

The hitherto mention'd External Specificks are afforded by Vegetables and Animals, which being Bodies of a lighter Texture, may be uppos'd to have their Parts more Effluviable: And therefore I hall now add two or three examples afforded by the Mineral Kingdom, which coniting of Bodies that never were living, and which are for the mot part very cloe and compact, are generally thought to have their Parts indipos'd to emit Effluvia.

I knew a Peron of great Learning, and by Profeion a Phyician, who enjoy'd a Health good enough, ave that uually after a few hours leep, he wak'd in the Night with great Terrors, follow'd for a long time with uch violent Palpitations of the Heart, as were very troubleom, and ometimes frightful to him. To remove this Ditemper, he try'd all that his Art uggeted to him, but without ucces, Whereupon he complain'd
of it to everal of his Acquaintance; and mentioning it one day among a Company of Merchants, whereof ome frequented very remote Country's; one of them told him, he would eaily relieve him, by a Remedy that had been found efficacious both upon himelf and others. This he told him was, to take divers flat and mooth Cornelian Stones, uch as they bring from the Eat-Indies, to cut Rings out of, and to ow eight or ten of them to a piece of Scarlet or Flannel, to be hung about his Neck, o as that the Stones may immediately touch the Skin over againt the Heart, and the Mouth of the Stomach. This Remedy the Phyician procur'd, and in no long time, found the great benefit of it, inomuch that he thought he might now ecurely leave off the ue of thee Stones, which he did once or twice out of curioity, as well as for his eae, but finding the Ditemper to return each time, within very few Weeks after he had laid aide his Remedy, he reolv'd
to keep it always on, as he had long uccesfully done, when he told me the tory. And to convince me, preented me with ome of the Cornelians, that he had, for fear of wanting them, procur'd in greater number than he needed at once. But ince I have not yet had occaion to make tryal of them, I hall not conclude that the Remedy will always ucceed, but only (which is enough for my preent purpoe) that 'tis at leat poible that uch an External Remedy may be very effectual.

I afterwards thought (which I here note, to add to the probability of what I have been relating) that pos;ibly thoe that firt made ue of the foremention'd Remedy, may have had a hint from what Galen aith of the Japer: Which Stone we oberve to be various in point of Colour, and I have een in the green mixtures of Red almot as deep as that of Cornelians. Of this Stone Galen relates that ome made Rings, in which were graven a Dragon having Beams
iuing from him, and commended it as very friendly to the Stomach, being apply'd to the Mouth of it. And tho' he omitted (and found he afely might do it) the Sculpture, he yet approves the Stones upon his own frequent experience, applying them almot as our Merchant did; Galen de Simp. Med. facultatib. Lib. â€¢ ono. Tit. de Lapid. Sane hujus (ays he) ego quo lapidis abunde feci periculum Torquem enim ex hujumodi lapillis confectum collo upendi ita ut lapides os ventriculi contingerent apparebant, autem nihilominus prodee etiami culpturam non haberent, &c.

I have lately mention'd the efficacy of a Cramp Ring upon ome Parts of the Genus Nervoum. But ome will perhaps think it more coniderable, if a Stone Ring worn on the Finger hall be able to work upon the Mas of Blood, and particularly that deprav'd Portion of it, that Nature relegates to uch ditant Parts as the Hemorrhoidal Veins. And yet the experienc'd Monardes, having derib'd
the Blood-Stone that is brought from New-Spain, and repreented it as a Japer, not only commends it againt Hemorrhages, being applyed to the Bleeding Part,Nic. Monard Simpl. Med. Hit. cap. 36. p. 329. but adds the following words, which declare that he peaks upon experience, Vidimus nonnullos Haemorrhoidum Fluxu afflictos Remedium enie, Annulos ex hoc Lapide confectos in Digito continue getando: nec non & Mentruum Fluxum iti.

I know you will expect here, that I hould not on this occaion pretermit the Lapis Nephriticus; of which ort of Stones, tho' many have been found ineffectual againt the Dieae that gives them their name, and tho' it be carce poible to chooe thoe few that are good, without having particularly and actually try'd them; yet that ome of them are of great virtue, we have the Tetimony of the inquiitive and judicious Boetius, and that other Learned Writer about Gems Johannes de Laet, whoe Praies
are confirm'd by the Hitorical Tetimonies of Monardes and others. But none that I have met peaks more home to our purpoe than a coniderable Merchant of Leipick, whoe rare Obervations are recorded by a man of very great reading the Learned Untzer. de Nephrit. Lib. 1. cap. 24. Untzerus, to whom I refer you, contenting my elf to mention in this place two of the ten Remarks he ets down, the firt, that the Merchant affirm'd to our Author, that by wearing this Stone for ome days, the calculous matter was o powerfully procrib'd, that a multitude of mall grains of Sand were expell'd, even at the corners of his Eyes. The like effect, to which he often oberv'd of that Remedy in divers other Perons. The econd, that by wearing the ame Stone, his Wife who was troubled with a great Catarrh found it coniderably Cathartick, inomuch that the firt day he was thereby purg'd fourteen or fifteen times, the next nine or ten times, and afterwards
had her Body kept very open. And he adds, that he found alo this Stone to operate like a Purge, tho' not o trongly upon himelf.

But enough, if not more than enough, of the vertues of Periapta and Appena epecially, ince more intances of them may be met with in ome other Papers: And even without them, or at leat with them, thoe particulars I come from mentioning, may furnih a ufficient Anwer to the Objection that has occaion'd them.

div.head: The Concluion.
div.p:
And now, Sir, you have what the conideration of the Nature of the things I treat of uggeted to me, about the Principal ways, by which I conceive Specifick Medicines may cure Dieaes, or at leat much leen them. I aid the Principal ways, becaue I am far from denying, that there may be many others, that mut
not here be mention'd, let I hould too much trangres the limits that become an Epitle; epecially, this being already far more prolix than I at firt intended; though I purpoely omitted the Authorities and Arguments of divers Phyicians and Chymits, that maintain that there are Specifick Medicines, bccaue they proceed upon Principles, (uch as ubtantial Forms, real Qualities, Ideas, or Chaoes and the like,) which I could not fairly employ, becaue I do not admit them. But though I forbore to lengthen my dicoure, by improper, and I hope needles Trancriptions out of others; yet 'tis long enough to prompt me, now at the cloe of it to remind you of two or three things that I declar'd at the beginning.

As Firt, that I did not pretend that a Specifick Medicine, or Nature by a Specifick, does commonly effect the cure by one of the particular ways that I propos'd, excluively to the ret; ince I rather think that oftentimes
two, and ometimes more, concur to the effect. Secondly, that I propos'd to my elf, to explicate the ways of working of Specifick Remedies, only in general. And Thirdly, that I did not aert, that the ways I pitch'd upon were the true and genuine ones, by which the Medicine does act, but only propounded them, as ways by which it may act: So that without being Dogmatical, I offer you my Explications, but as poible, and perhaps not improbable; and that may uffice for the occaion and cope of this Letter; in which I preume, you remember I aim'd but at hewing you, that the operations of Specifick Medicines are not irreconcileable to the Principles of the Corpucular Philoophy: Which I hope you will without reluctancy grant, if, by my good Fortune, the difficulties that made you heitate, eem to you to be leen'd by o barren an intellect as mine, dicouring of an abftruce ubject, which belongs to a proeion that I am not of. Upon which account
it may be jutly preum'd, that you, who have o much more agacity, and are o much more concern'd than I in the ubject I have been treating of; and who being a profes'd Phyician, have much more opportunity to dicover the various coures that Nature does or may take in curing Dieaes; will be able to give your elf far more atisfaction, than you could hope to receive from me, who have therefore propos'd to you my conjectures very diffidently, tho' I am very poiitive in aerting my elf to be
THE ADVANTAGES Of the Ue of SIMPLE MEDICINES.
Propos'd by way of INVITATION To it.
By the Honourable ROBERT BOLE Fellow of the Royal Society.

div.head: AN INVITATION To the Ue of Simple Medicines.
To the very Learned Dr. F.
Â§I.
div.p:
Since SPECIFICK MEDICINES, to deerve that name, mut be very Efficacious; and yet are for the mot part either imple or very little compounded, what has been aid about them in the foregoing Tract concerning Specificks may afford me a not improper rie to invite you, and thereby others of your Profeion, on
whom your Authority and Example may jutly have much influence, to eek after and Imploy, more than they are wont to do, uch Remedies as are either imple, or, when there happens a neceity to compound, are made up of no more Ingredients than are abolutely requiite to anwer the Indications, and the Phyicians Scope.

This ort of imple, or but lightly Compounded, Remedies, I am induc'd to prefer before thoe pompous compoitions, wherein men eem to have hop'd to urmount dieaes by the multitude of the Ingredients, upon the following Reaons. In all which I deire the advantages acrib'd to imple Medicines, above others may be undertood, not in an abolute and indefinite ene, but, as they peak caeteris paribus, which I here give you notice of once for all

And the firt advantage that I hall mention, is, That it is much les difficult, to foreee the operation of a
imple, than of a very compounded Medicine. So that Phyicians may proceed more ecurely, in imploying the former than the latter ort of Remedies. And indeed, if I do not greatly mitake, we often preume too much of our own Abilities when we believe that we know before hand, what the Qualities and Effects of a Mixture of many Ingredients of differing Natures, will be: Since many Bodies, by Compoition, and the change of Texture conequent thereupon, do receive great and unexpected Alterations in their Qualities. Several manifet Intances of this Truth may be met with in our Hitory of Colours; In divers of whoe Experiments, the Colour produc'd upon the Mixture of Bodies, is quite different from that of any of the Ingredients. As, when a blew Solution of Copper made in Spirit of Urine, does with Syrup of Violets, which is alo blew, produce a fair Green. And even ince I began to write this Section, a Tryal purpoely
made has afforded me a new Intance of the ame import.

For having put together ome Tincture of Iron, made with good Spirit of Vinegar, and a Volatile Tincture of Sulphur, (which I elewhere how how to make) from a Confuion of thee two very red Liquors, there emerg'd in a trice, a very dark and almot Inky Mixture, that retain'd nothing at all of Rednes.

The like notable changes I have everal times produc'd by Mixtures, in divers other Qualities of Bodies than their Colours, as in their Odours, Tats, &c. And why uch Alterations may not be alo effected by Composition, in ome of the Medicinal Qualities of Bodies, I do not yet ee. Quick-ilver it elf inwardly taken, does uually caue, either no manifet evacuation, or one that is made at the mouth: But if it be diolv'd in Spirit of Niter, and Precipitated with Sea-Salt, this white Precipitate being edulcorated, if it
be warily given in a jut Doe, doth (as far as I can yet learn) eldom fail of working, and yet eldomer work by Salivation, but by Siege. On the other ide Glas of Antimony (made per e) whereof a very few Grains given in ubtance, are wont to work violently upwards and downwards, being diolved in Spirit of Vinegar, (which is not eaily and quickly done) will not uually either Vomit or Purge, tho the Mentruum be drawn from it, and tho it be given in a larger Doe, than that of the uncompounded Glas.

And tho if Crude Antimony be flux'd with Niter and Tartar, as in the ordinary way of making Crocus Metallorum, there is produc'd, as is vulgarly known, a Medicine o Emetick and Cathartick, that an Ounce or les of the Wine wherein it has been infus'd, without enibly looing its weight, is wont to work trongly enough both upwards and downwards: Yet I have known ome that would without cruple, take
everal Grains of Crude Antimony in ubtance, and one particularly that continued the ue of it long, without being vomited or purg'd by it. And Tryals purpoely made have inform'd me, that if, intead of Salt-Peter and Tartar, Antimony be prepar'd with well dry'd Sea-Salt, and a little Salt of Tartar, tho both, thee amount not to above half the weight of the Niter and Tartar vulgarly us'd, yet the Antimony well flux'd with thee (for about an hour) is thereby o alter'd and corrected, that it affords an ueful Medicine, of which one may give from 12 or 15 Grains to half a Dram, or more in ubtance, without ordinarily working, either by Vomit or Siege, but uually by Sweat, and ometimes by Urine. Whence we may gather, that Antimony may be either made a more dangerous, or a more friendly Medicine, than of it elf it is, according to the Ingredients 'tis aociated with, tho thee be in themelves Innocent, and perhaps of kin to one
another. And even Chymits, as well as other precribers of Remedies, may be found, tho les frequently, to add to a Simple, uch things as rather deprave, than improve it. As one of their great Patrons (a happy Practitioner) complains, that Flower of Sulphur, by being ublim'd, (as by many it is) from Calcin'd Vitriol, and one or two other things, under pretence of purifying and ubtillizing it, does really acquire a hurtful Corroivenes. And if I had here the Leizure, Intances enough might be brought to how, that Chymits ometimes mitakingly produce by their additions to a Medicine, other Qualities, if not alo wore, than they deign'd or expected.

div.head: Â§ II.
div.p:
ANother Advantage of Simpler Medicines, is, that caeteris paribus, they are more afe than compounded ones, epecially if the Patients be valetudinary perons. 'Tis too much the cutom, both of many Herbarits, and everal other Writers on the Materia Medica, to give us rather Encomiums than impartial Accounts of the Simples they treat of; enumerating and magnifying all the vertues they have, and ometimes more than they have, without taking notice of their ill Qualities, upon whoe account nevertheles they may be inconvenient, if not hurtful and dangerous, to ome Contitutions, and in divers Caes. We know that divers Perfumes, as Musk and Amber, tho very grateful and refrehing to mot Mens Spirits, are yet very hurtful to many Women, and epecially to thoe that
are Hyterical. And I have known the mell of Musk very much diaffect an eminent Peron, though otherwie of a robut Contitution. I have alo known everal Perons, not all of them of the ame Sex, very much offended by the mell of Roes, which yet is very moderate, as well as to mot Perons, whether Men or Women, very grateful. I know a very great Peron to whom Honey, whether inwardly taken, or outwardly apply'd, is almot as hurtful as Poyon, having everal times produc'd trange and frightful Symptoms, even when the Patient knew not that any Honey had been imploy'd, and conequently could not be thus oddly ditemper'd by the force of Imagination. I think I have elewhere taken notice of the harm, that both I and others, ubject to Dieaes of the Eyes, have receiv'd, even by the moderate ue of Parley.

On this occaion I hall add what occurr'd to me long after I had dictated what I aid of Parley, that
Worm-wood, tho for many ues, an excellent Plant, has been found by many o apt to diaffect the head, and o unfriendly to the Eyes, that I have for ome years forborn it my elf for fear of the head-ach, and forewarn'd others of it that are ubject to weak Eyes. But I know a very Learned Man, whoe Elegant Pen has made him deervedly be taken notice of by many, who, tho he have naturally very good Eyes, found upon an Obtinate Tryal, that his Curioity educed him to make of the plentiful ue of Worm-wood-Wine and Beer, that within les than three Weeks, his ight was by degrees brought to be o weak, that he could not read a Gazet without Spectacles; but by totally leaving off Worm-wood, he quickly recover'd the vigour of his ight, without the ue of any of the helps that his profeion, which is Phyick, would have plentifully uggeted to him. this Relation I had from himelf oon after the thing happen'd, on
occaion of what I told him about Parley, &c.

And to peak more generally, I doubt not, but if Men were not o prepoes'd with the Praies that Authors give to Simples, that they overlook the Inconveniencies they may on divers occaions produce, we hould find in many Medicines bad Qualities, that are not yet taken notice of. And I have more than once hit, but too well, in the Prognoticks I made of the Hurt, ome Patients would receive by the ue of applauded Medicines, prescribe them, even by coniderable and Learn'd Men, when upon their Authority my warnings were neglected, and the ue of the Medicines unhappily perited in. I remember I once aw in the hands of a learned and curious Traveller into the Eatern Parts of the World, an Arabick Manucript about the Materia MÃ¨dica, which made me regret the los of the mot part of the little skill I once had in
that Language. For beides that it was written in a delicate hand, and the Letters in fit Places, curiouly adorn'd with Gold and Azure, the Method eem'd to be more accurate than any thing I had een on that Subject. And that which pleas'd me not a little, was, that the Author had been o wary, that after the columns wherein he taught, beides many other things, the Vertues, Does, &c. of every Drug he treated of, he had a ditinct column for the bad Qualities of it, and the contitutions and Dieaes wherein the ue of it may be dangerous or inconvenient. I think it therefore not unreaonable to upect, that, where a great many Ingredients are blended into one Medicine, one or other of them may have other operations, beides that deign'd by the Phyician; it may awaken ome leeping Ferment, and, if not produce a new Ditemper, may excite and actuate ome other hotile matter, that lay quiet in the Body before,
and perhaps would have been little by little ubdu'd by nature, if it had not been uneaonably rous'd and aited by ome Ingredient, that perhaps was needlely put into the Medicine. I have had o many unwelcome Proofs of this in my elf, that it engages me to be the more careful to caution others againt the like Inconvenience.

div.head: Â§ III
div.p:
ANother benefit accrewing from the ue of Simpler Medecines, is, that thereby the Patient may, without burdening his Stomach, or naueating the Remedy, take a larger Doe of the Medicine, or of that Ingredient of it wherein the vertue chiefly reides. For, whereas Phyicians are oblig'd to tint themelves in the Doe of the Medicine, for fear of diguting the Patient, or oppreing his Stomach; when there are many things heap'd together in a
moderate Doe of one compounded Medicine, thee Ingredients that are either uperfluous, or at leat are les efficacious, mut necearily take up a coniderable part of that determinate Doe, and conequently leave much the les of the more appropriated or ueful Ingredients.

To ay, that all the Ingredients that are thrut into a great compoition, are proper and conduce unto the ame purpoe, I doubt is not always true. And however is not a ufficient Anwer, ince it does not avoid the Inconvenience I have been objecting.

If a Baker, being to make the bet Bread he can, epecially for a Peron of a weak Stomach, hould to Wheaten Flower add the Meal of Rye, of Barley, and of Oats; tho' all thee Ingredients be good and nourihing, and each of them is by many us'd to make Bread, yet none will take him for a skilful Baker, and few would prefer this compounded Bread, to that more imple one
made of Wheat alone. And o to make good Gun-Powder a skilful man would not to Salt-Peter, Brimtone, and Charcole add Wax, Roin, and Camphire, though thee be very inflammable Subtances as well as Sulphur. And thus if one would make an Aqua Vitae, whereof but one mall cup were to be given for the quick recovery of fainting Perons, he would not with Spirit of Wine, or good Brandy, mix Mead or Cyder, and trong Bear or Ale, tho' each of thee be it elf a Spirituous Liquor.

Gum Arabick (whereof I prefer that which is tranparent and colourles) is precrib'd in everal compoitions, as a Drug proper to mitigate the harpnes of Urine. But by the quantity of the other Ingredients that 'tis mix'd and clog'd with, no more than a mall proportion of it uually comes to be given in one Doe. But when I have had the Curioity, leaving out all the other things, to give about a dram, or perhaps more
of it at one time, reduc'd by long Pounding (for the bet is very tough) to fine Powder, in a large draught of mall Ale or Beer, or ome other convenient Vehicle, I found very coniderable Effects of it. And I remember that a Gentleman of great note, coming to bid me farewel, becaue of a long and troublesome Journey, he was taking to Mineral Waters, which he intended to drink for many weeks, to eae him of a very painful harpnes of Urine; I that knew it was not venereal nor from the Stone of the Bladder (for when thoe Caues of the Strangury, the Medicine is not near o powerful) I deir'd him, before he went to make ue of this Powder, once, or (if there hould be need) twice a day. Which when he had done, it o reliev'd, him that he thought himelf quite cur'd, and forbore his intended Journey not only that Year, but the next. For the Chin-cough, as they call it in Children, whoe odd Symptoms do uually fright the Parents and Attendants,
and oftentimes frutrate the Endeavours of Phyicians, skilful in curing other Coughs, I have not known any magiterial compoition o effectual, as the imple Juice of Pulegium (by many call'd Pennyroyal) weetn'd a little with SugarCandy, and given long enough from time to time, in the quantity of a Childs Spoonful. (This Plant may be alo made to afford a Syrup, that will keep, and is ueful in Coughs, but which I doubt, is not o efficacious as the Simple Juice.) There are many and obvious experiments of the great efficay of o imple a Remedy as Aes Milk; (which yet in ome caes, I think inferiour to Goats Milk,) if it be given in a ufficient quantity, and for a competent time, there are alo many Intances of dangerous and tubborn Dieaes, that have been cur'd even by Common Cows Milk, when it has been very plentifully taken, and for a long continuance of time, and perhaps it is no les remarkable, that
in a far les time now and then, not extending to very many daies, Fluxes, as Dyarrhaeas, and tho more eldom even Dyenterical ones, are happily and eaily cur'd, as I have ometimes known by the bare ue of o light a Remedy as Milk, wherein, whilt it is gently boyling, an equal quantity of fair Water is little by little put, till at lat there remains but as much Liquor as the Milk alone amounted to at firt. This imple Alimentous Medicine being liberally taken (for it hould be us'd intead of all other Drinks whilt the Dieae continues) has been very frequently found to cure Fluxes, not all of one ort, in Ireland it elf, where that kind of Dieae is Endemical. And, tho I have formerly in another Paper recommended the ue of Paronychia foliis rutaceis, againt that ad and tubborn Dieae the Kings-Evil, yet I preume you will allow me, by the mention of a Tryal that was ince made with it, to give a notable Confirmation
of the Utility of giving an Alterative Simple, if need require, in coniderable quantity. A Phyician that I knew, was ent for to a Scrophulous Patient, in whoe Throat there was a Tumour, o big and o unluckily eated, that much compreing the Aophagus it rendr'd Deglutition exceeding difficult: So that being likewie o hard and tubborn, that tho the Phyician was alo a famous Chyrurgion, he could neither dicus it, or bring it to Suppuration; The Patient, tho rich, was in imminent danger of being tarv'd. In this Strait the Phyician remembring the Character I had given of Paronychia, or Whitlom Gras, ent about the Country to to get all that could be procur'd: And at firt gave a little of it in form of Infuion, in uch liquid Aliments as the Patient was able, with much ado, little by little to get down. And having by this means, after ome time, made the Deglutition les difficult, he gave the Remedy
more and more plentifully, to imbue the whole mas of Blood and Juices of the Body with the Vertue of the Herb, whereby the Tumour was at length reolv'd, and the Patient ecur'd, o much to the Phyicians Reputation as well as Profit, that, as he aid, he thought Gratitude oblig'd him to give me a Circumtantial Account of his Succes; as he very civilly did in a long Letter whereof I have given you the Subtance.

And tho I might here entertain you with the Vertues of ome other Simple Remedies, plentifully given, yet for brevity ake I hall rather oberve in general, That I doubt not but everal Simple Medicines (I peak of alterative not evacuating ones, would be found far more effectual than they are commonly thought, if they were given in a much larger Doe, and continued for a competent time. And probably o many Phyicians (epecially of the Old School,) would not be o
forward to reject either Specifick or imple Remedies, as having found ome of them not to anwer Expectation; if they would allow them as fair a Tryal, as they give to their own Precriptions, uch as the Chalybeats of the Shops, the Spaw, or Tunbridge Waters, the Decoctions of Guajacum, &c. which they often give with divers intermediate helps for a Month or ix Weeks, and ometimes for two Months together, without expecting that in a few weeks, much les in a very few days, they hould perform the cure.

div.head: Â§ IV.
div.p:
THE Fourth thing that may recommend the ue of Simple Medicines, is, That caeteris paribus they are more eay to be procur'd then Compounded ones. This Aertion needs little proof. And where everal Simples are requir'd,
one or more of them may oftentimes be difficult to be got; and all of them will till be troubleome to be fetcht, and to be made up into a Compoition. How ueful the knowledge of Parable Remedys may be, I have indeavour'd to how in a ditinct Paper; and therefore hall not dicoure of it here, but only add this one Obervation, that ome Medicines are o parable, that without reorting for them to Apothecarys hops (which are not every where at hand, nor always furnihed with them) we may find them in thoe of other Trades-men. Thus among Maons and Bricklayers we mot commonly meet with Quicklime; whoe bare Infuion in common Water [about a pound of the former, as 'tis more or les trong, to about three or four Quarts of the latter,] is of it elf a good Medicine in divers Caes, and as Experience has perwaded me, may be made the Bais of everal good Remedys, both Inward and Outward. Among the
latter of which may be reckon'd an Oyntment, that I uually kept by me for Burns, and made only by beating up trong Lime-Water with as much good Lin-eed Oyl, as could be made throughly to incorporate with it into a very white Unguent.

And I hall add concerning Lineed Oyl, (ince I have mention'd it) which is to be had in the hops of Varnihers and Painters; that of it elf, being exhibited in a large Doe, as of everal Ounces at a time, I have known it anwer the Commendations given it by eminent Phyicians, for breaking of Pleuritical Empyemas Simple Oyl of Turpentine alo, that may be uually had in the hops of the ame Trades-men, is in reality a noble Remedy in divers Affections, not only Inward, in which Chymits commend it, but Outward too. And I have had great thanks, both from Phyicians and Chyrugeons, for recommending the ue of it to them in Wounds, and particularly, where
one would expect little from it in the tanching of Blood, if it be eaonably apply'd very hot to the wounded Parts, where it alo much promotes a good Digetion. And I am confirm'd in the good Opinion I have long had of this Oyl, by the Information that's given me, That very experienced Chyrurgeon has lately been o charitable, as to publih a little Book, coniderable for the ueful Obervations it contains, of notable Cures done by him in Chyrurgical Caes, chiefly with Oyl of Turpentine. And I hall add, that a Chyrurgeon to a great Monarch, and one of the skilfullet men I ever met with of his Profeion, confes'd to me, that in an admir'd Cure that he had then lately done of a deperate Gangrene, in an eminent peron, very aged and almot bed-rid, the Medicine he acrib'd mot to, was the Oyl we were peaking of. And, becaue both he and others make much and good ue of Spirit of Wine in Gangrens, which yet is
thought to be unmingleable with Oyl of Turpentine, becaue if it be haken with it, it will quickly eparate again from it; I thought it might do Practitioners ome ervice, to make for them a Mixture of Oyl of Turpentine and Spirit of Wine, that might probably be more penetrant than the former, and les fugitive than the latter, which of it elf does not tay long enough upon the Parts 'tis apply'd to. Which Mixture I eaily made, by digeting for a while, and trongly haking from time to time, about equal parts by gues of good Oyl of Turpentine and throughly dephlegm'd Spirit of Wine, till this Liquor, by imbibing or diolving great tore of the Oleaginous Parts, have attain'd a Yellow Colour, for which reaon I call it the Tincture of Oyl of Turpentine.

And, ince my ubject has led me into the hops of Colour-ellers, I will before I leave them, take notice of one Simple that is wont to be found there, which if it were
not very offenive to the Tat, and omewhat diagreeable to the tomach, would be perhaps preferable for its Antinephritick Vertue, to the mot pompous Compoitions of the hops, and ome of the celebrated Arcana of the (vulgar) Chymits. I procur'd it, not without ome difficulty, from a Spagyrit, very well vers'd in the School of Paracelus and Helmont; who, tho a paring Commender of Remedyes, extoll'd this as the bet he had ever met with, to cure the Stone where it was not too big to pas, and to prevent the increae of it where it was. I have known it us'd in Clyters, with very good ucces in a Fit of that Dieae. But Inwardly I had no occaion to try it but upon my elf. And judging it innocent enough, (as indeed I found it rather Anodyne than Driving, I took it now and then, mix'd with Oyl of weet Almonds chiefly to allay the Tat, for otherwie I had long found that alone, inufficient) as a Preervative from Grave. And,
thanks be to God, I divers times thought it more manifetly effectual to that purpoe, by leening either the bulk of the Grains, or the quantity of the Sand, or both, than any of the Remedyes I had taken for prevention in everal years before. And yet I carce took a quarter of the Doe, precrib'd by the Spagyrit that communicated the Medicine to me; which in hort is (for I preume you would gladly know it) to take from time to time, by it elf or in ome convenient Vehicle two or three ounces of the expres'd Oyl of Walnuts, which, if the great talenes of it he requires be neceary, (which I mean to examine by Tryals) is carce to be had but at the hops of Artificers, becaue he would have it at leat a year old, and judg'd it the elder the better.

Before I quite leave the Shops of Trades-Men, I hall take notice of one Medicine more, that eems to have been firt lodg'd there, and from thence tranlated into the Shops of
Apothecaries. The Medicine I mean is Catile or ele Venetian Soap, (for either is often imploy'd in tead of the other) which being a Body abounding with Alcaliite Salts and Oleaginous Parts well combin'd, invited me to make ome Experiments with it, as a Subtance that may be applicable to good ues, not only Mechanical but Medical. Of ome of tho former ort I elewhere make mention. And as to its Medicinal vertues, I take notice in another Paper of its Efficacy againt the Jaundie; for which I have ince been inform'd, that, as naueous a Medicine as it is, 'tis in great requet among ome Skilful Men in Holland. And ome freh, but not ufficient, experience has recommended it to me againt the Stone. But that vertue of it which I as yet mot prize it for, and now intend to communicate to you, you will bet gather from the following Story. Having had ome dealings with a coniderable Merchant (of Cork, in Ireland) he adly complain'd
to me, that he was afflicted with a neceity of making Bloody Water to that degree, that he fear'd he mut oon quit his Profeion, being already unable to ride about his buines, and carce able to walk a foot the length of a Street, without tooping to make red Water. Hereupon I told him I had a Medicine, that, if he could diget the unpleaantnes of it, would, I thought, by the bleing of God, do good even in his cae. And it was only to crape with a Knife as much Catile Soap into a Spoon, as it would conveniently hold without being pres'd, i. e. neat a dram, and having fill'd the vacant part with mall Ale, or ome other, convenient Drink, to facilicate the wallowing o naueous a Remedy, wah it down with a omewhat large Draught of the ame Liquor, or other fit Vehicle, repeating the Doe twice or thrice a day, if need requir'd. The manifet relief he found by this eemingly depicable Medicine, within (if I miremember not) two or
three days, invited him to continue the ue of it a while longer, and afterwards to return me olemn thanks for it; declaring that now for four years together he had liv'd quite free from his Ditemper, without crupling to ride Journeys on Hore Back, as his occasions requir'd. To which he added, that in regard I had not confin'd him to ecrey, he preum'd I intended the Medicine hould do as much good as might be, and therefore crupled not to give it to everal others, who were likewie happily cur'd by the ue of the ame Remedy.
