Which Account was therefore the more welcom to me, becaue in the place were I liv'd, I had not opportunity to make further Tryals of its Efficacy. And on this occaion I hall beg leave to advertie you once for all, in reference to the Remedies deliver'd by me, either in this Paper or in my other Writings; That I am as enible as another of the almot inuperable Difficulty, of making any certain
Experiments in Phyick; and that, having of a long time (for Reaons given in due place) tudiouly, tho not unreervedly, declin'd the Occasions of giving (and conequently of reiterating) Medicines: I jutly deire that none of my Readers, and epecially that Dr. F. would too much rely upon them, till they have been more competently try'd, than perhaps ome of them, for want of opportunity, have been; and adminitred to Patients of differing Complexions, Ages, and other Circumtances.

You may find other Intances of the vertue of Parable, and ome of them unpromiing Medicines, in one of my Eay's Of the Uefulnes of Experimental Philoophy; to which I the les cruple to refer you, becaue I do not remember what I have there written many years ago, o perfectly, as not to fear that I might by enlarging this Section, put you to the trouble of reading ome things here that you have met with there already.
And yet I am omewhat incouraged both to mention to you that Book, and to preent you ome other Receipts in this Paper; becaue it has pleas'd God o far to bles divers of the Medicines I have there recommended, or do there mention, that they have been properous to many Patients, and not altogether unueful to ome noted Phyicians; and have procur'd me from both more thanks than I pretended to; beides inviting Encouragements to further Communications.

div.head: Â§. V.
div.p:
THE lat thing in order, but not in importance, that induces me to wih, that Phyicians would imploy Simpler Medicines as much as conveniently may be, is, that 'tis one of the likeliet ways, (and perhaps little les than abolutely neceary) to promote the Practical
knowledge of the Materia Medica. For, whilt in one Receipt a multitude of Ingredients are mingl'd, if not confounded, 'tis almot impoible to know with any certainty, to which of the Simples the good or bad Effect of the Remedy is to be attributed, or whether it be not produc'd by a Power, reulting from the particular Quality's of all of them, united into one Temperament, and by its means acting conjointly, and, as the School men peak per modum unius. So that by this way of heaping up or blending Simples into one compounded Remedy, I ee not how in many Ages Men will be able to dicover the true qualities good and bad, of the particular Bodies, that are compris'd under the name of the Materia Medica; whereas, when a Phyician often imploys a Simple, and oberves the Effect of it, the relief or prejudice of the Patient, may very probably, if not with medical certainty, be acrib'd to the good or bad Qualities of that particular Remedy.

And this difficulty of dicerning, what Ingredient it is of a very compounded Medicine, that helps or hurts the Patient, is much increas'd to thoe that affect to write Bills, wherein omething is precrib'd, which tho, becaue it goes under one name, paes but for one Ingredient, is yet a very compounded Body; as is evident, in thoe many pompous Receipts wherein Treacle, (that alone conits of above ixty everal Simples) Methridate, and divers other famous ancient compoitions; that each of them conits of good tore of Ingredients. I had once thoughts of drawing up a dicoure of the Difficulties of the Medicinal Art; and had divers materials by me for uch a work, which afterwards I laid aide, for fear it hould be miimploy'd to the prejudice of worthy Phyicians. But among the difficulties that occurr'd to me, I hall on this occaion mention one, which was; That 'tis a harder work than mot men think, to dicover
fully the nature, or the good and bad quality's in reference to Phyick, of this or that ingle Plant, or other Simple, that has a place in the Materia Medica. For beides the great difference that there may be in Plants of the ame denomiation, according to the Climate, Soil, the goodnes of the eeds that produce it, the culture, or the want of it, the time of the year, the eaonablenes or intemperatenes of the weather, the time and manner of gathering it, how it has been kept, the parts of it that are, and thoe that are not made ue of, together with other circumtances too many to be here enumerated: beides all thee, I ay, the unheeded Textures of parts that are thought of an uniform nature, and the length of time during which they have been kept, without being upected to be uperannuated, and indeed without being o, may o much vary the nature of a Plant, that I have ometimes almot in a trice
hewn the curious a notable diparity in the parts of the ame freh Leaf of a common Plant: And (NB.) I have found by Tryal purpoely made, that ome eeds of common ue in Phyick (and not putrefy'd) will, being ditill'd at one time of the year, afford an Acid Spirit or Liquor; but at another time of the year, tho detill'd the ame way without any addition, afford not an Acid, but a kind of urinous Spirit, that contains a volatile Salt, which in Smell, Tat, and divers Operations, I found to be of great affinity to the volatile Salt of Urine, or that of Harthorn. And indeed o many things may be pertinently and uefully propos'd to be inquir'd into, about this or that particular Plant made ue of by Phyicians, that perhaps they would be les inclin'd to compound numbers of them in one Receipt, if they were aware how much ueful employment the indagation of the Quality's of o much as a few ingle Plants would give
them: and yet without the knowledg of the properties of the eparated Ingredients, a Phyician precribes, it will be carce poible for him to know, with ufficient certainty, how the compound made up of them, will be qualify'd and operate, which reflection, I the les cruple to propoe, becaue I am conifirm'd in it by Galen himelf, Galen. de Con. p. Sec. Gen. lib. 1. who very Book, where he largely treats De Medicamentorum Compoitione, hath this Aertion; In univerum, nemo probe uti poit medicamento compoito, qui implicium vires prius non accurate didicerit.

I preume you will eaily allow, that much of what has been aid in favour of thoe imple Medicines we owe to Natures (or rather to its Authors) Bounty, may be extended to many of the Remedy's that are afforded us by the Chymits Art. For without now entering into the Quetion, whether the Spirits, Oyls, and Salts, that are obtain'd by what Spagyrits call Analyes by the
fire, are Principles in the trict ene of the word; it will carce be doubted, but that the Spirit, or the Oyl, or the Salt of a mix'd Body chymically reolv'd, is o lightly or unequally compos'd, that the Ingredient whence it takes its name, is far more predominant, than it was when combin'd with others, in the entire or not yet Analys'd Concrete. And that uch uppoed Principles, OF Medicines of a impler Order, may be very efficacious Remedys, may be jutly argu'd from the great and beneficial effects of uch as Oyl of Vitriol, Spirit of Urine (NB.) a Medicine of great ue both Inward and Outward, Spirit of Harthorn, Spirit of Niter, Spirit of Wine, and Oyl of Turpentine; of which lat nam'd Liquor I hall add, that, beides the vertues already acrib'd to it in this Paper, whilt it retains its implicity, it may in many Caes be imploy'd as a Mentruum, and by being combin'd with an Ingredient or two, be made to afford divers
Medicines, which tho but little compounded, are not of little vertue. For I have found it readily enough to diolve Camphire, Matick, and ome other Gums, of which Baloms may be made, and others may be obtain'd by the help of the ame Liquor, even from divers Mineral and Metalline Bodies. I will not init on o known a Medicine as the common Terebinthinate Balom of Sulphur; tho this be a Remedy, with as much as 'tis peculiarly extoll'd for Dieaes of the Lungs, (wherein yet its heat requires that it be very warily given to Patients of ome complexions) has vertues that are not confin'd to the Ditempers of thoe parts; ince both I and ome I commended it to, have found it very effectual (outwardly apply'd) in troubleome Haemorroidal Pains and Tumors: and (NB.) ome experience inclines me to think its vertues may not be much greater in Pulmonick than in Paralytick Ditempers: in which (lat) it may be
us'd, not only Outwardly, but chiefly Inwardly; and that in a pretty large Doe with a Cephalick, and, in ome Caes, an Anticorbutick Vehicle. But I hall rather take notice to you, that perhaps it will be found worth while to try, at leat in external Affects, the ue of divers Tinctures, and conequently Baloms that may be obtaind by the help of Oyl of Turpentine from divers olid Mineral Body's, upon which I have found by tryal, that this Liquor may be ting'd (tho not of the ame colour on all of them,) among which I hall name, beides Crude Zink, Crude Antimony, and even Crude Copper (in filings;) a noble Subject, Antimonial Cinnabar; from which, tho I found I could (but not hatily) draw a fine Tincture, I had not opportunity to make tryal of that promiing Medicine.

div.head: Â§. VI.
div.p: ANd as for thoe other Medicines, that are not made by bare Analyis, but by Syntheis or compoition; tho I think an experienc'd Chymit may, in many caes, with les uncertainty than a Galenit (who employs Crude Ingredients of a more compounded nature) foreee what quality the produc'd mix'd Body may have: Yet I could wih, that even the Spagyrits themelves were more paring, than many of them are, in the number of the Ingredients they imploy to compoe one Medicine. For mot of the Arguments, upon which I grounded my Invitation to the ue of imple Remedies, are applicable to Chymical ones, as well as others: And on this occaion I hall repreent two things.

Firt That in many caes, preparations skilfully diverify'd, may be uefully ubtituted to compoition:
Since one Body dexterouly expos'd to differing Operations, may acquire as various, or as coniderable, Qualities, as would accrew to it by the addition of uch other Bodies, as an ordinary Chymit would in probability aociate with it. Thus, not to mention Quick-ilver, Antimony alone, whether prepar'd without addition, as when Flowers of everal orts are made of the more Volatile, and true Antimonial Glas of the more fixt part, or being aociated but with one or two Ingredients, may afford a skilful Spagyrit, Medicines numerous and various enough, almot to furnih a Shop; or at leat to anwer the Phyicians Scope, where he would imploy an Emetick, a Cathartick, a Diaphoretick, a Deobtruent, a Diuretick, a Bezoardick or cordial Medicine; to name now no other Qualities, that may be found in ome Antimonial preparations, in a degree coniderable enough to ennoble them. Which. Intances, and others of the like nature
I preume you will allow me to make ue of in this dicoure, becaue, though I do commonly, yet I do not always, imploy the Term Simple Medicine or Remedy in the trict and abolute ene, but in a comparative one, that excludes compoitions of more than two or three, or at the utmot a very few, Ingredients.

Secondly, Without bringing together a Chaos, or o much as a coniderabe number, of Ingredients, one or two, or at mot three auxilary ones, if judiciouly choen and skilfully manag'd, may oftentimes produce more efficacious Remedies, than the admirers of pompuous Procees would expect, or perhaps be able to make thoe Procees vye with. The violently Emetick and purgative vertue of Glas of Antimony made per e, may be, as I elewhere how, more powerfully corrected by mere ditill'd Vinegar, than by many famous Stomachick and Cordial Elixirs, and other Elaborate Preparations. And ometimes a eemingly
improper addition may not only correct, but give new and unexpected vertues to a Drug. Thus, though Sublimatum corroivum be a mercurial concrete, o fretting, that a very few Grains of it may be able to kill a man; yet by adding and carefully uniting to it about an equal weight of running Mercury, there is obtain'd, when they are well united by Sublimations, a Compound that is o free from being corroive, that Chymits call it Mercurius dulcis, which though ome unwary Practitioners, as well Galenits as Chymits, have too often by their miimployment of it, dicredited, yet experience hows that in Skilful hands it may be uefully imployed, not only in ome venereal affections, but in divers other Ditempers. And I hall now add, that being carefully prepar'd, and well given, it may not only be freed from corroivenes, but much allay the Sharpnes both of ome emptying Medicines, & of ome peccant humors. To countenance
the latter part of which obervation, I hall acquaint you with one ue of it, that perhaps you have not yet made. I remember, I had an opportunity to oberve the Efficacy of Mercurius dulcis, in a tubborn dientery, that had baffled the Remedies of an eminent Phyician. But though a reflection on the vertue, I knew this Medicine to have, of allaying Sharp humors, and reiting Putrefaction, may jutly increae my favourable opinion of it; yet not thinking my Experience competent, I imparted it to an ancient and expert Chyrurgeon, that was the chief of thoe that belong'd to a famous and judicious General of an Army; who thereupon frankly confes'd to me, that this was his great Arcanum, wherewith he had cur'd many cores, or rather hundreds of Souldiers in this generals Army. Only, where as my way is to give from 8, or 10, to 12, or at mot 15 Grains of Mercurius dulcis for a Doe, made up with ome little Rhubarb, &c. Or other
Ingredient that would make it work, once, twice, or thrice with another Patient, (for the dientery it elf helps to carry off the Medicine) he, both to diguie it, and to make it more eaily takeable, made it up with Sugar and Mucilage of Cum-dragon into Lozenges, whereof one might containfrom near a Scruple to half a dram of the Mercurius dulcis, of which he order'd the Souldiers to take one at a time, without hindering their March; only bidding them have a great care, that nothing hould tick between their Teeth, or in their Throats.

3. But the efficacy of this imple preparation of Mercury, is much inferiour to that more imple, although more tedious, preparation of Gold, which was made the ame way in two differing Countries, by two dexterous Phyicians, both of them of my acquaintance. For though I had long been prejudic'd (not without pecious grounds) againt pretended Aurum potabiles, and other
boated preparations of Gold; (for mot of which I have till no overgreat eteem) yet, I aw uch extraordinary and urprizing Effects of the Tincture of Gold I peak of, upon Perons of great note, that I was particularly acquainted with both before they fell deperately ick, and after their trange Recovery, that I could not but change my former opinion, or a very favourable one of ome preparations of Gold; and I hould have thought that this Medicine (as little compounded as it is,) could carce he paid, by a great tore of the Noble Metal that afforded it, if it could have been made in great quantity, or without a great deal of pains and time. I can peak thus circumtantially, becaue by the kindnes of the Artits, and the pains I had pent in working on the ame Subject they make their Mentruum of, I o far knew, and partly (by themelves invited) aw, the preparation of it, that to bring home what has been aid, to the preent occaion) I can tell
you, that there is no Ingredient aociated to the Gold, ave one, that comes from above, and is reputed one of the implet Bodys in nature, and of which one may take two or three Ounces altogether unprepar'd, without the leat inconvenience. And yet the Doe of this almot inipid Medicine, that was given to an old Courtier, even in a violent Apoplexy, wherein other Remedies had by skil'ful men been us'd in vain, was but ix or eight drops.

In another very ancient and corpulent peron the Doe was greater, becaue the Tincture was more unripe and diluted; but the effect was as udden, tho the Patient was not bled, and tho there was not in either of thee two caes, any notably enible, evacuation made. [Both thee recover'd Perons are yet alive] the ame Medicine a while after, aved the life of another Gentleman I know, who, having lain above two and twenty days ick of an ill conditioned Feaver, was condemn'd
by three Phyicians, whereof one told me with great grief, that he would not out-live the next morning; and yet upon the taking of a large Doe of this Tincture, he was preently reliev'd, and from that time found a enible amendment towards a recovery, which he now injoys; tho he were then reputed to be about, if not above fourcore years old. Some other odd effects of this. Remedy I could tell you of: But it has already much well'd this Section, and yet I thought it not amis to relate thee things to you, both, becaue they are very pertinent to the cope of it, and becaue you may be, as I long was, prejudic'd againt Medicines made of o fix'd, and, as is uppos'd, un-alterable a Metal as Gold.

4. This is not the only Medicine made of that noble Body, of which I have known very notable effects. But, becaue they belong to another Paper, I hall not particularly mention them in this; but pas on to
tell you,The efulnes of Exp. Philoophy. that the Preparation of Silver, that I have long ince deliver'd in another Book, tho' it may eem but light, has been found very effectual, and much us'd, by one of the eminentet Phyicians of this nation, to whom I recommended it: and who acknowledg'd to me, that He gave it to Patients of very high Quality, tho' diguis'd, to avoid alarming thoe that are fearful of Chymical Medicines. And ince that I gave it to a great Lady that was Hydropical, and judg'd to be dangerouly ill, with notable ucces; and the Cure has already for ome years held good. But I confes to you, that I look upon Copper, and its Magitery Blew Vitriol, as a much nobler Subject to make Remedy's of, than Silver, and perhaps than Gold it elf. And if I were to make Phyick my Profeion, there is no Metal which I hould o willingly betow pains upon as Copper induc'd thereunto by the excellent and very extraordinary
Effects, (not all of them to be mention'd in this Paper, that I have had opportunity to ee, of ome Remedies, which tho' I could never learn how to make, I knew were made of that Metal, or Vitriol abounding in it. [But firt freed from all cruelticle violence.] And for appeaing of Pains, produc'd even by inveterate Maladies, the Laudanums) and other opiate Preparations, that are precrib'd and prais'd in Phyicians and Chymits Books, and much us'd (oftentimes with good ucces) in their practice, eem to me, bccaue of the Stupor, and ome other inconvenient Symptoms, they are wont more or les to be followed by, far inferiour to the Sulphureous Parts, as a Chymit would call them, of skillfully prepar'd Venus; thee being much more harmlely and friendly Anodynous. And I remember that an Empyrick, to whom, at his requet, I taught a very uncertain way (for it rarely hits) of making a kind of Sulphur of Vitriol alone, in the form
of a Brick colour'd Powder; came purpoely to give me olemn Thanks for the Reputation he had gain'd by that Medicine, of which the firt time he had the good luck to make it, he gave, as he was intructed, four or five grains of it, to a Woman that could not leep, but had been for divers months raving mad, [Maniaca.] which ingle doe not only gave her a good Nights ret, but brought. her to talk ene when he wak'd in the Morning. I knew alo a Chymit, that was much courted even by learned Doctors, for an internal Anodyne he us'd, and could ell at almot what rate he pleas'd, to take off inveterate Pains in the Heads and Shins of venereal Patients; and the ame Peron cur'd venereal Ulcers in a very hort time, only by trowing on them an Indolent Powder. And tho he was o hy, that he would not let even the Phyicians, I recommended to him, ee his Medicine, yet having one day been told of a kindnes I had done
him, unknown to him; he took it o well, that he not only allow'd me to ee and handle his Medicine, but when I gues'd by the ponderounes and effects; of it, that it was ome. Preparation of Mercury fixt with Sulphur of Venus, he frankly acknowledg'd to me, that, tho it would indure not only Ignition, but a trong & lating fire, that in the former part of my Conjecture (that the Body of it was Mercurial) I was in the right; and in the latter part I hot very near the Mark; but added, that that the true Sulphureous parts of Venus were in his way o difficult to be obtain'd, and requir'd o much time, that he could eldom prevail with himelf, (who indeed was voluptuous enough) to go through o troubleome a work. And in effect I found, upon various Tryals, the contituent Parts of that Metal to be much more trictly united than the generality even of Chymits imagaine. For the extraordinary effects of this Medicine, I can refer you to
the Tetimony of very ingenious men of your own Profeion, (and probably acquaintance too.) And ince I know you tudy Helmont, I preume you will the more readily believe them, if I put you in mind of that notable Paage, where he ays: Nihil, aeque victorioe in Humidum Radicale, agit atque primum ens cupri, vel ad vitam longam Sulphure vitrioli et benignius; ideoque Sulphur Philoophorum indigitat. But my intended Brevity forbids me to init longer on this Metal, or to take notice of more than one other Metal. And becaue that of Steel, Phyicians as well as Chymits make great variety of Remedies, ome of which are produc'd by Preparations light enough; And the like may be aid of Mercury, witnes the Remedy formerly commended againt the Worms, made of nothing but crude Quick-Silver barely decocted in common water: For this reaon, I ay, I hall pitch upon Lead, whoe calx diolv'd in Spirit of Vinegar affords
as you know, Saccharum Saturni, which tho o eay and imple a preparation, is a magitery that has more vertues than every Phyican knows, or perhaps o much as upects; epecially in mortifying harp humours in the Eyes, which I have known or made it do ometimes almot in a trice. [But I do not think it afe to make the Plantain or Roe-water 'tis to be diolv'd in, coniderably trong of it.] And for Burns, I have eldom een any thing equal to it, and therefore have often us'd it upon my elf (barely diolv'd in Common, or ele Plantain Water.) But I fear 'tis not o afe as effectual, in ome inward Ditempers of the Bowels, that are judg'd to be caus'd by Acid humours; unles it be very warily and skilfully given. [But as to its external ue, I preume, I need not tell o skilful a Doctor as you (NB.) how great it is in healing, and in the mean time appeaing, the Pains of divers orts of Ulcers. And therefore I hall mention but one
Particular, which 'tis like you have not met with; namely, that I know a very Ancient and experienc'd Peron, who, beides a vat practice otherwie, was Chyrurgeon to a great Hopital; who profeing much kindnes, and owning ome obligation to me, confes'd to me, that amongt all the Medicines he has try'd to top Bleeding, and prevent Accidents in Amputations, that which he oftenet us'd, and mot rely'd on, is a olution of Saccharum Saturni in Plantain Water (or for a need in pure common Water:) for having diolv'd j. of the former in about a Pint or pound of the latter; as oon as ever the Limb or other part is taken off, he immediately apply's Stupes drench'd in this Liquor, as hot as the Patient can well endure; and having bound them carefully on, he makes, no hat to take them off, but allows the Medicine time enough to perform its operation: To countenance this I would tell you an odd experiment of mine, of the efficacy
of a Saturnine Liquor to reit Putr faction, in the Bodys of Animals, but that the relation would take up too much time.]

5. Perhaps I need not tell you, that I could here mention divers other Experiments, as well upon Saturn, as the other Metals I have nam'd above; but that my Scope confines me to uch Preparations, as wherein the Metaline Subject is compounded but with very few others; and alo that of thoe that are more remote from implicity, you may meet with everal in ome of my other Papers, which I am not in this to defraud.

What has been above noted about Metals, may be extended to Minerals: namely, that when there is need to compound them, it may of tentimes be ufficient to aociate them with one or two, or at mot a very few Auxiliary Ingredients, if I may o-call them; this is apparent in everal ueful Preparations of Antimony, that are vulgarly enough known.
To which divers may be added that are made of common Sulphure, by light additions. Of which ort, becaue I elewhere deliver everal, I hall now mention but one, which though I have many years ago decrib'd in the Hitory of colours, I hall not cruple to take notice of here, becaue I there conider not its Medicinal vertues, which yet are very great, epecially in Athmas and Coughs, in which I do not remember that I ever gave it without benefit to the Patient; nor was it les uccesful in the hands of Phyicians, that were willing to try it for me, epecially in thoe of a Peron, who though well furnih'd with choice Remedies of his own, often came to me for a upply of this Spirituous and penetrating Tincture, with which he aur'd me he did notable things in Athmatical caes; and particularly in one that was very obtinate, and had lated many years. But not having had quite o many opportunities as I wihed of giving it my elf, I hall
be glad, that further Tryal may be made of it by o skilful an Adminitrer as you. And therefore let you hould not have the Book lately refer'd to at hand, I hall here repeat, that our Medicine is made of Flowers of Sulphur, exactly mix't with an equal weight of finely powder'd SalArmoniac, and omewhat more than an equal weight of good Quick-lime, eparately reduc'd to a Suttle Powder. For thee three Ingredients being diligently and nimbly mix'd, and put into a Retort, to be plac'd in a and Furnace, and fitted with a large receiver very well luted to it. This Mixture, I ay, being duly ditill'd in uch veels, will afford a Blood red and moaking pirit, exceeding Sulphureous both in mell and oven Mechanical Operations. And in this Ditillation the Sulphureous Parts ometimes came over accompany'd with uch tore of aline ones, that a good part of what pat into the Receiver hot into the form of a Volatile Sulphureous Salt. And I
remember that having for curioity's ake added to the Fluid Tincture a due proportion of an Ardent Spirit (uch as that of Wine) exactly dephlegm'd, I had a Mixture (whether in the form of a Coagulum or not) which afforded me ome odd Phaenomena not here to be mention'd, and which we ubled with a gentle fire to unite them into a compoition that may for ditinction ake be call'd Sa trium regnorum, becaue it contains Urinous Particles, Vinous ones, (and perhaps ome of Soot) and Sulphureous ones: whereof the Firt belongs to the Animal, the Second to the Vegetable, and the lat to the Mineral Kingdom, as Chymits are wont to peak. But what vertues this Salt (that would preently gild Silver,) and the Spirit that may be made to accompany it, may have in Phyick, I had not occaion to try. But yet I have mention'd it upon the by, that you may make ue of it, if you think it worth while to do o. To whch I hall here preent you with no Inducements,
ince I perceive that the Particulars above mention'd about imple preparations of Gold and other Metals, have already made this Section enormouly great. And yet I hope you will not be dipleas'd at it; ince to o ugacious a peron as Dr. F. thee paages may afford ome not altogether ueles hints: and at leat 'tis an Encouragement to Indutry, to know that the ubjects a man works on are capable of affording Excellent things.

div.head: Â§. VII.
div.p:
1. I Foreee it may be objected againt the frequent ue of imple Medicines, that oftentimes it happens that a Dieae, or a morbiick Matter, is not the effect of a ingle Caue, but is produc'd by the concurrence of two, or perhaps more, Caues, which producing everal ymptoms, 'tis not probable that one Simple Drag will be able to anwer thoe different Indications
This Objection I confes is coniderable, & there are caes wherein I acknowledg it to be o weighty as to invite & warrant a Phyician, to imploy in them a Medicine coniting of more Ingredients than one or two; which I can admit without prejudice to any Deign, ince I formerly declar'd I did not intend to perwade you to conine your elf to Simple Remedy's (o much as in the late ene above intimated of that Term) but only to imploy them where they may uffice; and where they cannot to make ue of Medicines as little compounded as the cae will permit,

2. But having premis'd this Advertiement, I preume I may offer you two or three coniderations, that may leen the force of the lately propos'd objection And firt, tho I readily grant, that there are Dieaes, whereof each may proceed from differring caues, and that a Remedy may be available againt it, When 'tis produc'd by one of thoe
caues, without being o when it flows from another; yet it may alo eaily happen, that in one cae the Dieae may be cur'd by one imple Medicine, and in another, by a Remedy not compounded. Nay, it may alo happen, that the ame imple may cure a Ditemper, by which oever OF the two caues it is produe'd. This I have in another Paper endeavour'd to make out. And what we ee of the Effects of the Jeuits Powder, as they call it in different kinds of Agues, as Tertians, Quartans, &c. and of pacating Medicines (mot of which indeed owe their vertue to Opium, but ome are Mineral, and have nothing of the Poppy in them) in appeaing Pains produc'd by Humours, and other caues very differing; may keep what has been aid from appearing improbable, And, if I mitake not, it may divers times happen, that, whatever it were that at firt produc'd a portion of Morbiick matter, that firt produc'd matter, is the caue of the continuance of the Dieae,
by vertue of ome peculiar Texture or Noxious Contitution, which if a generous Medicine can detroy, the Dieae will, at leat little by little, ceae.

3. It not unfrequently happens, that everal Symptoms that eem very differing, may o depend upon the primary or principal caue of the Dieae, that if a Medicine, how imple oever, be capable to detroy that caue, all the various Symptoms will, by degrees at leat, vanih of themelves: as we often ee, that when Mercury, tho perhaps but crude, is skilfully apply'd, and raies a kindly alivation, a great variety of Inconveniencies that afflicted a Venereal Patient, and eem'd to require many differing and topical Applications, are remov'd by the ame Remedy; inomuch that not only frightful Ulcers, but uch Modes as one would think earce poible to be diipated by the tronget Plaiters, are ometimes happily cur'd by well prepar'd Quickilver, taken in at the mouth,
as I have been aured by more than one eminent Phyician upon his own Experience, And tho not unfrequently there be everal, & ometimes very different Symptoms, that accompany that Dieae of children that in England we call the Rickets; (and of which there dye everal almot every week in London alone) yet that Medicine which I have elewhere decrib'd under the name of Ens (primum) Veneris [made of trongly calcin'd and well dulcify'd Colcothar of Dantick Vitriol, and elevated with Sal Armoniack into the form of a reddih ublimate] has prov'd, by Gods bleing on it, o uccesful, that partly by a Siter of mine, (to whom I communicated it) and partly by my elf, and thoe I directed to take it, or to give it; I think I may afely ay, that two or three hundred children have been cur'd by it, and that almot always without the help of any other inward Medicine, or uing any Topical application at all.

4. But the main thing that I intended, by way of anwer to the foreeen Objection, was, that in a imple Medince nature her elf does oftentimes o well play the Apothecary, as to render the compoitions made in his hop unneceary. For, tho we are wont to look upon this or that Plant or Mineral, as an entire and imple Body, yet we may much mitake, if we look upon it as a Homogeneous one. In everal Plants that are organical Bodies, this Truth is manifet; as for intance, in Oranges the Succulent part is oure and cooling, but the Yellow Rind coniderably bitter and hot: and o in Lemons the Pulp, the Yellow part of the Rind, and the eeds have their differing Qualities and Medicinal vertues. And even in uch vegetable Subtances as are Homogeneous as to ene, there may be Parts, whoe operations may be not only differing, but contrary; as is manifet in the Root, we call Rhubarb, which affords as well notably Atringent, as Laxative and
Purgative Parts. And o in Minerals themelves good and clean Lead-Oar, for intance, tho an uniform body as to ene, conits of very diimilar Parts, and affords Sulphureous and perhaps other Recrements, beides Malleable Lead, which is it elf a compounded Body. Thus alo hining Marcaites, tho they appear Homogeneous, will by barely being expos'd for a competent time to the moit Air, afford an Efflorecence, that is perfectly vitriolate, and conequently contains an Acid Salt, two kinds of Sulphur, a Terretrial Subtance, and at leat one Metal, (for oftentimes it holds both Copper and Iron, tho one predominate,) which lat nam'd Subtances themelves are neither of them imple Bodies.

5. And if we admit the Chymical Analyis of mixts to be genuine, we hall find that almot all thoe that belong to the Vegetable Kingdom, or to the Animal, and many that are refer'd to the Mineral Kingdom, how uniform oever they may appear to
the Eye, do each of them contain everal different, and ometimes hotile Subtances. Thus Harthorn, tho it appears a dry and Homogeneous Subtance, will in ditillation afford a volatile Salt, an urinous Spirit, a waterih Liquor, or Phlegm, a wiming Oyl and a inking one, a white and porous Earth, or Terra damnata, and perhaps ome, tho but very little, fixt Salt. Thus alo in the Vegetable Kingdom, Tartar, for intance, may without addition be made to afford, as Experience hath aur'd me, a volatile Salt very like that of Urine, a Phlegme, an Acid Spirit, another Spirit too which I have elewhere given the name of Adiaphorous, two faetid Oyls, whereof one will ink in Water, and the other wim on it, an Earth or Terra Damnata, and a fixt Lixivial Salt, upon which the newly mention'd Acid Spirit manifets uch a hotility, that when they are put together, they tumultuate with noie and Bubbles, and
in the Conflict mortify each other. And thus likewie in the Mineral Kingdom, not to repeat what I lately aid of the compoundednes of Vitriol; Nor confidently to urge the Opinion of divers Eminent Phyicians, that Mars (as they call Steel and Iron) affords parts whereof ome are Atringent, and other Operative, becaue I am not yet ure thee contrary qualitys, do not proceed from the differing degrees of Fire, and other Circumtances of the preparations of the Metal: We ee that Native Cinnabar affords by Ditillation, beides running Mercury, a dry ubtance, whence I have obtain'd a Sulphur that would preently gild Silver, and a Terretrial ubtance, whoe nature I had not occaion to examine. And I the rather take notice of thee differing Parts in Native Cinnabar, becaue it is a Mineral that I much eteem; and tho here in England it is very rarely, or carce at all imploy'd as an inward Medicine, yet I know ome
Forraign Phyicians of everal Nations, that look upon it, as one of their chief Arcanums, and both ue it, and conceal it, accordingly. But I do not willingly imploy it, till it has been prepar'd, by grinding it exactly, upon a Porphire, or other fit Stone, as a Painter would do to make a Pigment of it, and by freeing it from certain Salts, that often undicernedly adhere to it, and ometimes may be hurtful; which is done by Firt wahing it very carefully with boyling Water, and then, after it has been throughly dry'd, by burning upon it everal times, one after another, ome Vinous Spirits perfectly dephlegm'd. [The Doe, if it be to be long continu'd, may be three, four or five grains: but when 'tis to be given but eldom, and for an urgent Cae, it may be from ix or even, to ten or twelve grains.

div.head: Â§. VIII.
div.p:
1. WHat has been aid in the foregoing dicoure, to manifet, that a imple, whether Organical or not, may notwithtanding its intirenes or its eeming Homogeneity, contain or afford very, diimilar parts; may help us to conceive, that being really a compounded Body, it may afford Parts differing enough to anwer differing Indications, or attain everal Scopes, that are wont to be look'd on by Phyiciaus as neceary, or at leat very ueful to the cure of this or that dieae; as in many Diarrhaeas or Fluxes of the Belly, whereas, 'tis judg'd requiite firt to evacuate the Peccant matter, and then to give Atringents, to hinder the immoderate evacuation wherein the dieae is thought to conit; Rhubarb anwers both thoe Indications, by its Purgative and its more terretrial
Parts, whereof the former dipatch their work firt, which makes the Atringent operation of the latter eaonable and afe.

2. I have divers times oberv'd, that o common and depicable a imple as Ground Ivy, has perform'd things whoe variety eem'd to argue, that it contains Parts of very differing vertues (as of opening, contemperating, healing, &c.) and is thereby capable of anwering differing intentions, epecially in Ditempers of the Lungs & Breat, & indeed partly by the Syrup of it, partly by the infuion of the Leaves, and partly by Medicines made of them in a conitent form; the happy Effects of this imple have procur'd me the thanks of divers coniderable perons, ome of which had before unuccefully us'd many Precriptions of learned men. And I remember I knew an Ingenious Peron, who being Mater of a coniderable manufacture, which was gainful to him, whilt his Servants continu'd tolerably
well, was very much incommodated and perplex'd, to find them o obnoxious to violent Colicks, (which he imputed to the Copious Steams of the Vinegar his Art requir'd,) that he was forc'd almot weekly to allow them ome days of ceation from working, to preerve or recover themelves. And I remember that from this Inconvenience, he was at length, as himelf confes'd to me, in great part freed by making his workmen frequently ue a trong Infuion or Tincture of the Leaves of our ground-Ivy made with (not pure or dephlegm'd Spirit of Wine, but) good unrectify'd Nants Brandy.

I could here add divers other ues, both Internal and External, of this eemingly depicable Plant, there being carce any one Englih Herb known to me, of which, for its manifet vertues, the Experience of others and my own have given me a greater Eteem. And I am apt to think, that the Efficacy which this and ome other Simples, that the
fear of Prolixity makes me ilently pas by, would be found both greater and more various than they are commonly thought, if Phyicians in precribing Medicines would more often either ordain Simple ones, or at leat aociate but very few together, and compenate the mall number of Ingredients, by the greater quantity of thoe that are the mot appropriated or operative, and by periting in their ue for a competent time.

Tho 'tis not every efficacious Simple, or but lightly compounded Remedy, that can fitly be imploy'd about the Proof of what I am now endeavouring to how, yet I hall ubjoyn uch Intances, as will, I hope, uffice for the preent Occaion.

Mineral Waters, as well Acidubae, as the German Spaw, our Tunbridge, &c. as Thermae, uch as thoe of Bath, &c, tho but Natural Medicines; and ome of them but outwardly adminitred, are notoriouly known in their native implicity to be able
one of them ingle, frequently to cure everal Dieaes, and conequently to take off a good number of differing Symptoms, that afford various Indications. It may help much to make it probable that the ame Simple may comprie Qualities fit to anwer differing Scopes, and thereby cure differing Symptoms, if it be conider'd, that there are everal Poyons that do each of them produce Symptoms not only very frightful, but very various, and yet all thee have been oftentimes conquer'd by a Specifick Antidote, that is perhaps but a imple Herb or other uncompounded Drug. I had once, (and but once) the opportunity of making a Tryal, whereof I hall now give you a brief Account, of the vertue of a tone taken out of the Head of an enormouly great African Serpent; which tone was affirm'd to the Poeor of it, Governour of the famous Englih Eat India Company, to be highly available againt the Bitings of all venemous Animals.
The ubtance of the Experiment (to give it you in hort) was this, I caus'd a young Cat to be bitten by a fierce and highly irritated Viper, which o inrag'd the Cat, that in revenge he endeavour'd to bite off her Head, which he took in his Mouth, and did not let go, till, as the Spectators concluded, he had bit him again, at, leat by the tongue; oon after which venemous Hurt, the Cats Head well'd very much, and tho he oon grew o weak, that he was not able to tand on his Legs, but lay along on the ground, yet he eem'd to be grown quite mad, for he foam'd at the Mouth, and napt at the end of a Wand, or uch like things, that were but held near him; and, which was more, in his rage bit one of his own Legs, that lay not far from his Mouth, much to the urprie of the Spectators. But, tho in this deperate condition it eem'd in vain to attempt any thing for his Recue, becaue one could make him take nothing, and every one was affraid
to come near him; yet having mix'd a little of the powder'd tone with ome ponfuls of fair Water, it was by the help of the neck of a glas Retort, that we imploy'd in tead of a funnel, pour'd by degrees upon the Cats Mouth; which lying open, tho he endeavour'd to hake it off, yet ome of it was concluded to have got in; and within one hour or two after, if not les, he did, to the no mall wonder of the Bytanders, get upon his Legs again, and not only eem'd to have much of the Tumidnes of his Head, but readily enough took the Medicine I caus'd to be given him; and would probably have cap'd very well, if, whilt I was at dinner with the Company, ome unruly People had not hurt him more mortally than the Viper had done.

Phyicians and others have oberv'd in the Plague a great variety of Symptoms, among which there are divers, whereof each, if ingle would pas for a particular Dieae. And this
diverity of Symptoms may be not unfrequently oberv'd, not only in Petilences that happen at times, or in Countries ditant from one another, but in the ame Plague reigning in the ame Place. And yet 'tis poible, that a imple Remedy may be available againt this o multifarious or manifold (if I may o call it) and violent a Dieae. Of Which Obervation (to omit what might be alledg'd out of ome other Authors) I hall give one intance out of Galen himelf, who, treating at large of the Terra Samia, takes occaion 'to bring in the vertues of Bolarmony (Bolus Armena) which I hould gues by his manner of mentioning it to have been little, if at all, known to Phyicians till his Time. This Earth, that appears a Body o imple and uniform; He not only commends for evearal Dieaes, as pitting of Blood, Fluxes of the Belly, Dyenteries Catarrhs, Defluxions from the Head upon the Breat, Difficulty of Breathing thence inuing,
and even Ulcers of the Lungs; but adds, what makes very much and directly for our purpoe, in the following words. In magna hac Pete, Galen. de Simpl. Med. Facult. lib. ix. Tiul. de Terra Samia. (whereof he had poken before) cujus eadem facies fuit atque ejus quae Thucidydis memoria graabatur, quotquot hoc Medicamen bibere celeriter curati unt. [The way of giving it (which I add by the by, becaue it may ometime or other be of ue) was this, Bibitur, ays He, ex vino albo conitentiÃ¢ tenui, modice diluto, i aut planÃ¨ Febri careat, aut leviter eÃ¢ teneatur, in gravius febriat, admodum aqueo.] And o excellent a Medicine did this imple one prove in that terrible Plague, that our Author ayes, Quibus non profuit omnes interiere; Scil. cum nec alio quovis Medicamine, juvarentur: unde colligiter, concludes He, quÃ²d iis duntaxat non fuerit auxilio qui plane erant incurabiles.

3. There are few Dieaes that put on o many forms, or are attended
with greater variety of Symptoms, than that which Phyicians call Affectio Hyterica, and whoe Paroxyus or effects are vulgarly known in England by the name of Fits of the Mother. And yet we have often remov'd, and not eldom in a quarter of an hour or les, Hyterical Paroxyus and Symptoms, and ometimes uch as made the Patient woon or lye along as almot dead, by the bare Odour, of well rectify'd Spirt of Hartshorn, or the mere pungent and powerful mell of a Spirit of Sal Armoniack, which by a peculiar way I made very trong, purpoely for external Ues. And if I had not out of the experienc'd Monardes,
See Nicol. Monard Simpl. Med. Hitor. Cap. 36. P. m. 329. Phyician to the Viceroy of the Spanih Indies, already mention'd in another Treatie an Anticorbutical Gem; I would here add another Remedy againt the ame Dieae, more coniderable to my preent purpoe, ince 'tis only a imple Stone outwardly apply'd.

4. But, becaue I think not fit in this place to init on a Tetimony already alledg'd, tho its Credibility, as well as that of the thing to be confirm'd by it, may be much favour'd by what has been related, concerning the Vertues of Stones outwardly apply'd, in the latter part of the Dicoure about Specificks: For this Reaon, I ay, I hall add a couple of other remarkable Intances, of the Efficacy of even Dry and Solid Bodies, tho but externally apply'd in Dieaes attended with everal, and divers of them uncommon Symptoms, whereof, whatever many think of the harmlesnes of our Englih Vipers, I have here known everal Intances, in Men as well as Brutes. And yet in thee dangerous Caes, many that come from Eat India extol the great Efficacy of ome of thoe Stony Concretions, that are aid to be found in the Heads of a certain kind of Serpents about Goa, and ome other Eatern Countreys: for tho mot Phyicians reject or quetion the
Power acrib'd to thee tones, for curing the Bitings of Vipers, and tho I do not wonder at their diffidence, becaue in effect many of the tones brought from India are but counterfeit; and of thoe that were really taken out of Serpents, everal, for a Reaon I mut not tay to mention, are inignificant; (and uch perhaps were thoe that the learned and curious Redy made his Tryals with) yet there are others, whoe vertues are not well to be deny'd. For, not to build on vulgar Traditions, which are but too often deceitful, one of the eminentet Doctors of the London Colledge aur'd me, that he had, with one of thee tones, done, tho contrary to his expectation; a notable Cure, which he related to me at large. And one of our chief Englih Chyrurgeons affirm'd to me, that he had done the like upon another peron; both of thee Cures being perform'd by the bare application of the Stone, to the Place bitten by the Viper or Adder. And a very
intelligent peron, who had the direction of a coniderable Company of Traders in Eat India, where he long liv'd, aur'd me that he had with this Stone cur'd everal perons of the Hurts of venemous Animals, But, this Tetimony is much les coniderable, as to the number of Cures, than that of a great Traveller into the Southern parts of the ame India, who, tho he were bred by a famous Carteian Philopher, and were forward enough to dicredit vulgar Traditions about the Countreys he had long liv'd in; yet being for thoe Reaons ask'd by me, what I might afely believe of the Stones I peak of, eriouly affirm'd to me, that he had cur'd above threecore perons of the Bitings or Stings of everal orts of poyonus Creatures; and that he perform mot of thoe Cures, by the outward Application of one Stone; becaue, finding it excellent, He was invited to keep to it, epecially in difficult. caes. And this ame Experience of my own, made with a Genuine
Stone of this kind, upon the Bodies of Brutes, much inclines me to give credit to. But, becaue this Stone is afforded by an Animal, I hall add the vertues of another, that properly belongs to the Mineral Kingdom; in a Dieae, whoe Symptoms, tho not o various, are ometimes dangerous, and too often mortal.

To hew you then, that in pite of great Cloenes and Hardnes, a imple Remedy outwardly apply'd, may be a very effectual one, I hall inform you, that tho the Solid I am peaking of pat for a Bloodtone, yet by its colour and ome other viible qualities, I hould rather have taken it for an Agat. It was but about the bignes of a mall Nutmeg, and had in it a Perforation, by which a tiring pat through it, to faten it to the Part affected. This Stone had been long kept in the Family that poes'd it, when I aw it, being for its rare vertues left by one to another. But, to omit the reports that
went of it, the notable cae, that makes it pertinent for me to mention it here, was this. An ingenious Gentleman, that was a man of Letters, and when I aw him, was in the Flower of his Age, and of a complexion o highly Sanguine, as is not uually to be met with, was from time to time ubject to Hemorrhages at the Noe; o profue and o difficult to be retrain'd, that his Phyician, tho a Peron famous and very well skill'd in his Art, told me he often fear'd he hould looe his Patient, and that he would be carry'd away by this unbridled Ditemper But when good method and variety of Remedies had been try'd, without the deir'd ucces, this Stone was at length obtain'd from an ancient Kinwoman of the Gentlemans, to tye about his Neck, o as to touch his naked Skin. This when he did in the Fits, it would top the Bleeding; and if he wore it for ome coniderable time together, he all that while continu'd well, as both his learned
Phyician and himelf inform'd me. And, becaue I was apt to acribe omewhat of this effect to imagination, on, the Patient told me, that a while before one of the chief Women in the City, (whom he nam'd to me) fell into o violent a Bleedings, that, tho' it brought her into a Swoon, yet that it elf, which is omewhat trange, did not hinder her to Bleed on, till the Stone, having been ty'd about her Neck, made her ceae to do o, tho' he knew nothing of its having been apply'd to her. And this it elf is les trange than what the Gentleman affirm'd to me of the Power of this Gem, as it may deervedly be called. For his complexion inclining him, as was above intimaed, to breed great tore of Blood, his Doctor thought fit to order him, for prevention, to breath a Vein, from time to time, which when he was about to do, he was obliged to lay aide the Stone for a while, becaue, whilt he kept it on, the Blood would not iue out, at leat with the requiite Freedom.

But how far have I already pat beyond the deigned Limits of this little Tract! wherein I at firt intended, but to lay before you the five chief advantages I had oberv'd, mere imple Remedies to have of very compounded ones; and briefly to propoe the main grounds, on which I acrib'd thoe advantages to uch Remedies. But tho' the better to keep this writing from being prolix, I deign'd that it hould conit chiefly of uch particulars, as I could bet pare from other Papers; And tho' for that reaon I have purpoely omitted many parable, and other but little Compounded or Elaborate Medicines: Yet I now perceive that, o many new particulars having offer'd themelves on everal occaions, whilt I was writing, my Pen has lipt into the mention of many more Receipts, and Hitorical paages, than were at firt intended. But believing the ubject to be very ueful, and not depairing but that the things deliver'd on it may not
be altogether ueles; I dare hope you will pardon uch faults, as only my deire of making the Parts of this mall writing, rather erviceable than Methodical or well proportion'd, drew me unawares into. But whatever were the caue of my Prolixity, the bulk which I ee this Paper has already well'd to, admonihes me, that I ought to put a peedy period to it, without pending time olicitouly to declare in what ene I commend the Medicines deliver'd in this Invitation, For by recalling to mind, what I have formerly wrote (in a Treatie you have been pleas'd to perueSee the Appendix to the I Section of the II Part of the uefulnes of Exper. Philoophy. p. 389-390 And of the 2d. Edition.) about the Limitations, with which I would have the praies I give of Tome Remedys undertood, and the cautions with which I would have them adminitred; you will eaily be perwaded, that looking upon them but as fit Tools in a skilful Workmans Hands, I do not pretend that any of
them hould do the Offices both of Phyick and Phyician too: and that I propoe not the Medicines mention'd in this hort Paper, as ure Specificks, but as intances that there are Remedies, which notwithtanding their being but imple ones, may be very good ones.
